[[Image:Rolle's_theorem.svg|300px|right]] In [[calculus]], '''Rolle's theorem''' states that if a function ''f'' is [[Continuous function|continuous]] on a closed interval <math>\left[a,b\right]</math> and [[derivative|differentiable]] on the open interval <math>\left(a,b\right)</math>, and <math>f\left(a\right) = f\left(b\right)</math> then there is some number ''c'' in the open interval <math>\left(a,b\right)</math> such that
: <math>f'\left(c\right) = 0</math>.
Intuitively, this means that if a smooth curve is equal at two points then there must be a stationary point somewhere between them. Just continuity is not sufficient. (However, differentiability is not quite necessary; see note below.) For example, if
:<math>f\left(x\right) = |x|</math>
the [[absolute value]] of ''x'', then we have that
: <math>f\left(-1\right) = f\left(1\right)</math>
but there is no ''x'' between -1 and 1 for which <math>f'\left(x\right) = 0</math>. This is because that function, although continuous, is not differentiable at ''x''=0.
A version of the theorem was first stated by [[India]]n astronomer [[Bhāskara II|Bhaskara]] in the 12th century.[http://www-history.mcs.st-andrews.ac.uk/history/Projects/Pearce/Chapters/Ch8_5.html] A proof of the theorem had to wait until centuries later when [[Michel Rolle]] in [[1691]] used the methods of differential calculus.
== Proof == The idea of the proof is to argue that if <math>\ f(a) = f(b)</math> then <math>f</math> must attain either a maximum or a minimum somewhere between <math>a</math> and <math>b</math>, and <math>\ f'(x) = 0</math> at either of these points.
Now, by assumption, <math>f</math> is continuous on <math>\ [a,b]</math>, and by the [[continuity property]] attains both its maximum and its minimum in <math>\ [a,b]</math>. If these are both attained at endpoints of <math>\ [a,b]</math> then <math>\ f</math> is constant on <math>\ [a,b]</math> and so <math>\ f'(x) = 0</math> at every point of <math>\ (a,b)</math>.
Suppose then that the maximum is obtained at an interior point <math>\ x \in (a,b)</math> (the argument for the minimum is very similar). We wish to show that <math>\ f'(x) = 0</math>. We shall examine the left-hand and right-hand derivatives separately.
For <math>\ x_1</math> less than <math>\ x</math>, the quantity <math>\ f(x)-f(x_1) \over {x-x_1}</math> is non-negative since <math>x</math> is a maximum. Thus the [[limit (mathematics)|limit]] as <math>x_1</math> approaches <math>x</math> from below is non-negative. (Note that we assume that <math>\ f</math> is differentiable to guarantee that the left-hand and right-hand derivatives exist; it does not follow from the other assumptions).
For <math>\ x_2</math> greater than <math>\ x</math>, the quantity <math>\ f(x)-f(x_2) \over {x-x_2}</math> is non-positive. Thus the limit as <math>x_2</math> approaches <math>x</math> from above is non-positive.
Finally, since <math>\ f</math> is differentiable at <math>\ x</math>, these two limits must be equal and hence are both 0. This implies that <math>\ f'(x) = 0</math>.
== Relaxed assumptions == The theorem is usually stated in the form above, but it is actually valid in a slightly more general setting: We only need to assume that
: <math>f : \left[a,b\right] \rightarrow \mathbb{R}</math>
is [[continuous function|continuous]] on <math>\left[a,b\right]</math>, that
: <math>f\left(a\right)=f\left(b\right)</math>
and that
: <math>\forall x \in \left(a, b\right) ,\; \lim_{h \rightarrow 0}\frac{f\left(x + h\right) - f\left(x\right)}{h} \in \left[ -\infty,+\infty \right]</math>
== Generalizations ==
The [[mean value theorem]] gives a similar statement but for functions that do not have the same value at the end points; that is, <math>f(a) \neq f(b)</math>. The conclusion is that there is a point of the domain where the instantaneous slope equals the mean slope. Rolle's theorem can be used to prove the mean value theorem and vice versa.
We can also generalize Rolle's theorem by requiring that ''f'' has more zeros and greater regularity. Specifically, suppose the following * the function ''f'' is ''n'' times differentiable: <math>\dipslaystyle f\in C^{n-1}[a,b]</math>, and <math>\displaystyle f^{(n)}(x)</math> exists on <math>\displaystyle (a,b)</math>, and * the function ''f'' has ''n''+1 roots: <math>\displaystyle f(x_i)=0</math> for distinct points <math>x_0, \ldots, x_n</math>, in <math>\displaystyle [a,b]</math>. Then there is a <math>c\in (a,b)</math> such that <math>\displaystyle f^{(n)}(c)=0</math>.<!-- boy, a diagram sure would be handy here to explain this; just even showing a function with three roots and its derivative with one root would do-->
== See also == *[[Mean value theorem]] *[[Extreme value theorem]] *[[Intermediate value theorem]] *[[Linear interpolation]]
==External links== * [http://www.cut-the-knot.org/Curriculum/Calculus/MVT.shtml Rolle's and Mean Value Theorems] at [[cut-the-knot]]
[[Category:Calculus]] [[Category:Mathematical theorems]] [[Category:Real analysis]] [[Category:Proofs]]

revision.comment: Biography of Muhammad Luqman, the Lahore based Broadcast Journalist.
revision.text: Muhammad Luqman Sheikh is a Lahore(Pakistan) broadcast journalist. Born on October 17, 1964, he did his matriculation from M.C. High School Faisalabad, Punjab, Pakistan. He did F.Sc (Pre-Medical) and BA from Government College Faisalabad. He received Master's degree in International Relations from Quaid-e-Azam University Islamabad (Pakistan) in December 1987. Started his practical life by joining an American Pharma Company, Abbott Laboratories as Territory Manager in 1988 but resigned March 1989. Joined Faisalabad Grammar School as teacher in March and taught O level classes till May 1990. Worked as visiting lecturer at Islamia College of Educatin , Faisalabad from May 1990 to November 1990. Joined Associated Press of Pakistan (APP) the official news agency of Pakistan as a reporter. Performed as Station Manager Multan and Faisalabad and worked as Senior Reporter at Lahore Bureau of APP till November 2007. Joined Technology Upgrdation and Skill Development Company (TUSDEC) in November 2007 and worked as Head Media and Public Relations till September 16, 2008 before joining Samaa TV as senior reporter/assignment Editor. Still working as Senior reporter of Samaa TV at Lahore.

page.title: A-level Computing/AQA/Problem Solving, Programming, Operating Systems, Databases and Networking/Problem Solving/Reverse Polish Notation

revision.text:
<NOINCLUDE>
{{CPTPageNavigationU3|
 | Prev = Backus-Naur Form (BNF)}}
{{displaytitle|title=Problem Solving: Reverse Polish Notation}}
</NOINCLUDE>

'''Reverse Polish  notation''' (otherwise known as post-fix, RPN for short) is a way of representing mathematical equations. The notation is used because the format that the equation is in is easier for machines to interpret rather than the notation we are used to, infix notation, where the operator is in between the numbers. The equation can be complex or simple. RPN doesnt require brackets as the equations are layed out in such a format that it isn't required for machines to understand.

The name RPN is named after [[w:Jan Łukasiewicz|Jan Łukasiewicz]], a Polish  logician who invented Polish notation (prefix notation) some time in the 1920's.

== Reverse Polish Notation ==
Reverse polish notation should be ordered like this:

 <FirstNumber> <SecondNumber> <Operation>

Rather than the normal convention(infix) of:

 <FirstNumber> <Operation> <SecondNumber>

== Examples ==

===Examples of equivalent equations:===

{| class="wikitable"
|-
! <big>PostFix</big> !! <big>Infix</big> !! <big>Answer</big>
|-
| <big>3 4 +</big> || <big>3 + 4</big> || <big>7</big>
|-
| <big>3 5 6 + *</big> || <big>(5 + 6) * 3</big> || <big>33</big>
|-
| <big>2 4 / 5 6 - *</big> || <big>(2/4)*(5-6)</big> || <big>-0.5</big>
|-
| <big>2 3 ↑</big> || <big>2³</big> || <big>8</big>
|}

=== Implementation as a Stack ===
[[File:CPT-RPN-example1.svg|thumb|600px|centre|An example of how a stack can be used to compute reverse polish notation.]]

===YouTube Video Example===
A video example can be seen here from Computerphile on Youtube: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7ha78yWRDlE
<ref>Video link to Computerphile a Youtube channel: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UC9-y-6csu5WGm29I7JiwpnA</ref>

==Practice Questions==
{{CPTExercise|title=Exercise: Infix to RPN Conversion}}
{{CPTQuestion|Convert ''x + y'' into RPN.}}
{{CPTAnswer|''x y +''}}
{{CPTQuestion|Convert ''(x + y)*z'' into RPN.}}
{{CPTAnswer|''x y + z *''}}
{{CPTQuestion|Convert ''3 / (5 + y * x)'' into RPN.}}
{{CPTAnswer|''3 5 y x * + /''}}
{{Robox/Close}}

{{CPTExercise|title=Exercise: RPN to Infix Conversion}}
{{CPTQuestion|Convert ''x y *'' into infix.}}
{{CPTAnswer|''x * y''}}
{{CPTQuestion|Convert ''5 y + z x 3 - * /'' into infix.}}
{{CPTAnswer|''(5 + y) / ((3 - x) * z)''}}
{{Robox/Close}}

==References==

== Welcome! ==
[[Wikibooks:Welcome|Welcome]] to Wikibooks, Stonemountain420!
[[File:Crystal Clear app kedit.png|20px|link=|alt=]] '''First steps tutorial'''
'''Wikibooks is for [[WB:AGF|collaborative]] development of free [[WB:WIW|textbooks]].''' You do not need technical skills to [[Using Wikibooks|contribute]]. You can [[WB:BOLD|easily change most books]]. Please [[WB:CHAT|introduce yourself]], and let us know what [[WB:PROJECTS|interests you]]. If you already contribute at other Wikimedia projects, our [[Wikibooks:Wikibooks for Wikimedians|Wikimedia Orientation]] should quickly get you started.
(Would you like to provide [[Template talk:Bigwelcome|feedback]] on this message?)
[[File:Icon apps query.svg|20px|link=|alt=]] '''Getting help'''
* Read the [[Using Wikibooks]] book for a friendly introduction to the project, or our [[Help:Contents|help pages]] for more information. * You can get friendly help from the community in the [[WB:HELP|user assistance room]] or our [[irc:wikibooks|IRC channel]]. * Upload freely licensed files to [[commons:Wikimedia Commons|Wikimedia Commons]]. You may [[WB:RFP|request permission]] to upload [[w:fair use|fair use]] files locally. Please include author and source {{tl|information}} and a {{nowrap|{{tl|non-free use rationale}}}} for [[WB:FU|non-free]] files.
[[File:Nuvola filesystems trashcan full.png|20px|link=|alt=]] '''Made a mistake?'''
* You can [[WB:REVERT|restore]] a previously saved version. * Pages should follow the [[WB:NP|'''Book Title/Chapter Title''']] naming convention. * Need to rename a page? Use the ''move'' tab (is available once your account is 4 days old - until then, ask for [[WB:HELP|help]]). * To request a page be deleted, add {{tlx|delete|''your reason''}} to the top of the page. * Was a page you made deleted? Please read the [[WB:DP|deletion policy]], and check the [[Special:Log/delete|deletion log]] to find out why. Also check the [[WB:RFD|RFD]] archives if applicable. You can request undeletion at [[WB:RFU]], or ask the administrator who deleted the page.
[[File:Transmission icon.png|20px|link=|alt=]] '''Goodies, tips and tricks'''
* Please fill in [[WB:ES|the edit summary]] and [[WB:PREVIEW|preview]] your edits before saving. * Sign your name on [[WB:TALK|discussion pages]] by typing ~~~~ * User scripts can make many tasks easier. Look at the ''Gadgets'' tab of [[Special:Preferences|''my preferences'']]; check off the boxes for the scripts you want, and hit ''save''!
Thanks, --[[User:Xania|ЗAНИA]] [[Image:Flag_of_Estonia.svg|15px]][[User talk:Xania|talk]] 18:54, 14 May 2014 (UTC)
== Linking == Hi, just for your information here are the easy ways to make links on Wikibooks: * To link to another book just write: [[book name|whatever]] which will look like: [[book name|whatever]] * To link to an external site just write: [http://www.google.im Google] which will look like: [http://www.google.co.im Google] --[[User:Xania|ЗAНИA]] [[Image:Flag_of_Estonia.svg|15px]][[User talk:Xania|talk]] 20:03, 14 May 2014 (UTC) == Deletion Request == Hi. :I have added the deletion request for your three pages as requested in the page content. Might I suggest, in case, you believe that you might be required to create more pages, but not sure of the same, you can utilise the sandbox for better understanding. This would assist all. The latest revision can be viewed here [https://en.wikibooks.org/w/index.php?title=A-level_Graphic_Products/Edexcel/Unit_2_(Exam)&curid=300026&diff=2655586&oldid=2655579], [https://en.wikibooks.org/w/index.php?title=A-level_Graphic_Products/Edexcel/Unit_3_(Exam)&curid=300023&diff=2655585&oldid=2655580], and [https://en.wikibooks.org/w/index.php?title=A-level_Graphic_Products/Edexcel/Unit_1_(Coursework)&curid=300025&diff=2655584&oldid=2655578]. :Danke. [[User:Harrybrowne1986|Vishal]][[User Talk:Harrybrowne1986| Bakhai]] - [[Special:Contributions/Harrybrowne1986|Works]][[Image:Flag_of_India.svg|15px]] 14:52, 16 May 2014 (UTC) == [[A-level Graphic Products]] == Hello. :I see that you are doing a good job of creating the better articles out here. Might you be able to add some links, or sources to the reference lists, or rather paste few of the links from your source at my talk page please. It would assist myself in reviewing it better. Also, in case you are expanding it further, you would like to remove the '''stub''' template, once its expanded properly. Danke. [[User:Harrybrowne1986|Vishal]][[User Talk:Harrybrowne1986| Bakhai]] - [[Special:Contributions/Harrybrowne1986|Works]][[Image:Flag_of_India.svg|15px]] 15:08, 17 May 2014 (UTC) == Bookcat == I have now fixed the book category. Hope it helps. Danke. [[User:Harrybrowne1986|Vishal]][[User Talk:Harrybrowne1986| Bakhai]] - [[Special:Contributions/Harrybrowne1986|Works]][[Image:Flag_of_India.svg|15px]] 17:18, 17 May 2014 (UTC) == Categories == {{tmbox|type=notice|text='''Please use our [[WB:CAT|category system]] to help people find new pages and books.''' Every page in a book should include {{tl|BookCat}} or a book navigation template. A book's main page should include {{tl|subjects}} with a few [[:Category:Subject|subjects]] that reflect the book's specific scope. You can read [[Using Wikibooks]] to learn more about [[WB:WIW|Wikibooks]], or ask questions in the [[WB:HELP|Assistance Reading Room]]. Thank you }} --[[User:Xania|ЗAНИA]] [[Image:Flag_of_Estonia.svg|15px]][[User talk:Xania|talk]] 18:53, 28 May 2014 (UTC)

A Go language binding for GLPK has been published at https://github.com/lukpank/go-glpk.

page.title: Talk:Models and Theories in Human-Computer Interaction

revision.comment: Xania moved page [[Talk:Models-and-Theories-in-Human-Computer-Interaction]] to [[Talk:Models and Theories in Human-Computer Interaction]]: removing unnecessary hyphens
revision.text:
== Introduction ==
Being that the nature of the field of Human Computer Interaction is that it is interdisciplinary, theories and models proceed and are adapted from many other disciplines. There are but a few of which could call "genuinely native" HCI theories and models. To complicate matters, computerized systems change at a vertiginous pace and changes are often surreptitious. It seems as if [http://www.kurzweilai.net/ Kurzweil] was not as far off from fact with his predictions. Through this course, we will learn, critique, apply, and expand theories and models to make them relevant to the state of the field.
Looking through the [http://www.sigchi.org/ Association of Computer Machinery Special Interest Group on Computer Human Interaction's (SIGCHI)] repository, this researcher has not been able to zero in on a book that addresses the needs of a course in models and theories for our discipline. Therefore, we will use our textbook and articles to guide our discussion and we will collaborate in documenting the state of matters through this WikiBook.
'''Register, sign in, and contribute. '''
''Dr. Z ''

As a [[cookbook:Cereal Grain|cereal grain]], it's the most important [[w:staple food|staple food]] for a large part of the world's human population, especially in Asia, the Middle East, Latin America and the West Indies. It's one of world's three most produced grains along with [[w:wheat|wheat]] and [[cookbook:corn|maize]] (corn).

{{AM&C-top|FUN=1|both=1}} ==Introduction== Running Content Manager can sometimes be frustrating given the kludgy nature of the user interface. The worst problems occur after downloading a route which suddenly bequeaths a variety of faulty content items, with some of that missing other dependencies, and so instead of playing, you have to track what is going on. Perhaps you do as I do and keep a log file or spreadsheet of downloads. ==Adding kuids to a list== [[File:Trainz CM Tricks-01_in TS10 (w-small icons)_Using an ORed_KUID_list to view fixed asset and then to see certain dependencies not in first KUID group.png |thumb|right|476px|{{bull}}1) Keep 'just fixed' asset Woodchips 2BayOp... by setting up an OR (2nd) 'Asset KUID' field with the Woodchips gondola's kuid. {{bullR}}2) Then commit the asset. 3) This asset then showed ''the 'Faulty Dependency Puzzle' piece'', so got this view by examining the assets dependencies (RMBHdrag etc){{bullR}} 4) The faulty dependencies are not in the just downloaded list, but are present, or might be (''very, very, most commonly... On the DLS so you need them listed in the main view for a drag N drop into the Download Helper pane).{{bullR }} 5) So continue the second kuid list with the missing or faulty kuids so you can deal with all that now. ]] Adding kuids to a Search list you want to keep static requires a trick--a double use of a kuid list. ;Consider this common scenario # Assume you keep a log file of downloads by version, or put that up in a spreadsheet # Assume the aftermath of a download—you want the main view list captured and put into a text file anyway, so do that or paste them into an Open Office (Calc) spreadsheet. # Assume further, the download was a route, and the dependencies, all of them new to you ran to the hundreds. # You've got 8-12 new faulty assets, scattered through that big list in the main view # and further, you run more than one Trainz, so you need to track fixed assets so you can output CDP's for the one's you fix.
(Elsewhere in AM&C you were advised, if your ISP speed is high enough to separately download assets instead of copying or exporting cdp files across versions. We repeat that advice here!--Fabartus) # If you are just focused on faulty assets, your initial list is too long and unweildy, so after selecting the download by 'View in Main List' you set an auxiliary filter {{kp|Faulty|True}}, so now you can see just the errors. # ==Notes and Footnotes== {{notelist}} {{clear}} {{TRS-underconstruction}} {{reflist}} {{AM&C-bot|IT=1|FUN=1}}

page.title: Structured Query Language/NULLs and the Three Valued Logic

revision.text:
{{Java Programming/Navigation|previous=Recursions|next=Transactions}}
__TOC__
== The Problem == As mentioned in a [[../SELECT: IS NULL Predicate|previous chapter]] of this wikibook and in [[w:Null (SQL)|wikipedia]] sometimes there is no value in a column of a row, or - to say it the other way round - the column stores the ''NULL marker'' (a flag to indicate the absence of any data), or - to use the notion of the SQL standard - the column stores the ''NULL value''. This NULL marker is very different from the numeric value zero or a string with a length of zero characters! Typically it occurs when an application yet hasn't stored anything in the column of this row. (A hint to Oracle users: For Oracle the NULL marker is identical to a string of zero characters.) The existence of the NULL marker introduces a '''new fundamental problem'''. In the usual boolean logic there are the two logical values TRUE and FALSE. Every comparision evaluates to one of the two - and the comparisions negation evaluates to the opposite one. If a comparision evaluates to TRUE, its negation evaluates to FALSE and vice versa. As an example, in the usual boolean logic one of the following two comparisions is TRUE and the other one is FALSE: 'x < 5', 'x >= 5'. Imagine now the new situation that x holds the NULL marker. It is not feasible that 'NULL < 5' is true (1). But if we say, 'NULL < 5' is false (2), its negation 'NULL >= 5' is true (3)! Is (3) more feasible than (1)? Of course not. (1) and (3) have the same 'degree of truth', so they shall evaluate to the same value. And this value must be different from TRUE and FALSE. Therefore the usual boolean logic is extended by a third logic value. It is named '''UNKOWN'''. All comparisions to the NULL marker results per definition in this new value. And the well known statement 'if a statement is true, its negation is false' gets lost because there is a third option. SQLs logic is an implementation of this so called [[w:Three-valued logic|trivalent, ternary or three-valued logic (3VL)]]. The existence of the NULL marker in SQL is not without [[w:Null (SQL)#Criticisms|controversy]]. But if NULLs are accepted, the 3VL is a necessity. This page proceeds in two stages: First it explains the handling of NULLs concerning comparsions, grouping, etc. . Second it explains the boolean logic for the cases where the new value UNKOWN interacts with any other boolean value - including itself. == Step 1: Evaluation of NULLs == === Comparision Predicates, IS NULL Predicate === SQL knows the six comparision predicates <, <=, =, >=, > and <> (unequal). Their main purpose is the arithmetic comparision of numeric values. Each of them needs two variables or constants ([[w:Infix notation|infix notation]]). This implies that it is possible that one or even both operants hold the NULL marker. As stated before the common and very simple rule is: "All comparisions to the NULL marker results per definition in this new value ('''unkown''').". Here are some examples: :* NULL = 5 evaluates to UNKNOWN. :* 5 = NULL evaluates to UNKNOWN. :* NULL <= 5 evaluates to UNKNOWN. :* col_1 = 5 evaluates to UNKNOWN for rows where col_1 holds the NULL marker. :* col_1 = col_2 evaluates to UNKNOWN for rows where col_1 or col_2 holds the NULL marker. :* NULL = NULL evaluates to UNKNOWN. :* col_1 = col_2 evaluates to UNKNOWN for rows where col_1 and col_2 holds the NULL marker. The WHERE clause returns such rows where it evaluates to TRUE. It does not return rows where it evaluates to FALSE or to UNKNOWN. In consequence it is not garanteed that the following SELECT will return the complete table ''t1'': -- This SELECT will not return such rows where col_1 holds the NULL marker. SELECT * FROM t1 WHERE col_1 > 5 OR col_1 = 5 OR col_1 < 5; Of course there are use cases where rows with the NULL marker must be retrieved. Because the arithmetic comparisions are not able to do so, another language construct must do the job. It is the ''IS NULL predicate''. -- This SELECT will return exactly these rows where col_1 holds the NULL marker. SELECT * FROM t1 WHERE col_1 IS NULL; === Other Predicates === For the other predicates there is no simple rule of thumb. They must be explained one after the other. The IN predicate is a shortcut for a sequence of OR operations: -- Shortcut for: col_1 = 3 OR col_1 = 18 OR col_1 = NULL SELECT * FROM t1 WHERE col_1 IN (3, 18, NULL); -- the NULL case will never hit with the IN predicate! -- a second example which is a little more complex -- WHERE col_1 IN (SELECT col_x FROM t2 WHERE id < 10); Only the two comparisions 'col_1 = 3' and 'col_1 = 18' are able to retrieve rows (possibly many rows). The comparision 'col_1 = NULL' will never evaluate to TRUE. It's alway UNKNOW, even if col_1 holds the NULL marker. To retrieve those rows it's necessary - as shown above - to use the 'IS NULL' predicate. The subselect of an EXISTS predicate evaluates to TRUE if the cardinality of the retrieved rows is greater than 0, and to FALSE if the cardinality is 0. It is not possible that the UNKNOWN value occurs. -- The subselect to t2 can hit some rows - or not. If there are hits in the subselect, ALL rows of t1 -- are returned, else no rows of t1 are returned. SELECT * -- The select to table t1 FROM t1 WHERE EXISTS (SELECT * FROM t2 WHERE id < 10); -- The subselect to table t2 The LIKE predicate compares a column with a regular expression. If the column contains the NULL marker, the LIKE predicate returns the UNKOWN value, what means that the row is not retrieved. -- The LIKE retrieves NO rows if col_2 contains the NULL marker. SELECT * FROM t1 WHERE col_2 LIKE 'Hello %'; === Predefined Functions === The [[../SELECT: Predefined Functions#Aggregate functions|aggregate functions]] COUNT(), MIN(), MAX(), SUM() and AVG() ignores such rows where contains the NULL marker. On the other hand COUNT(*) includes all rows. If a parameter of one of the [[../SELECT: Predefined Functions#Scalar functions|scalar functions]] like UPPER(), TRIM(), CONCAT(), ABS(), SQRT(), ... contains the NULL marker the resulting value is - in the most cases - the NULL marker. === Grouping === There are some situations where column values are compared to each other to answer the question, whether they are distinct. For usual numbers and strings the result of such decisions is obvious. But how shall the DBMS handle NULL markers? Are they distinct from each other, are they equal to each other or is there no answer to this question at all? To get results, which are expected by (nearly) every end user, the standard defines "Two null values are not distinct.", they build a single group. SELECT DISTINCT col_1 FROM t1; retrieves one and only row for all rows where ''col_1'' holds the NULL marker. ... GROUP BY col_1 ...; builds one and only one group for all rows where ''col_1'' holds the NULL marker. == Step 2: Boolean Operations within 3VL == After we have seen how various comparisions and predicates on the NULL marker produces TRUE, FALSE and UNKNOWN it's necessary to explain the rules for the new logic value UNKNOWN. === Inspection === A first elementary operation is the inspection of a truth value: is it TRUE, FALSE or UNKNOWN? Analogous to the ''IS NULL predicate'' there are three additional predicates: :* IS [NOT] TRUE :* IS [NOT] FALSE :* IS [NOT] UNKNOWN -- Check for 'UNKNOWN' SELECT * FROM t1 WHERE (col_1 = col_2) IS UNKNOWN; -- parenthesis are not necessary -- ... is semantically equivalent to SELECT * FROM t1 WHERE col_1 IS NULL OR col_2 IS NULL; In the abstract syntax of logical systems ''p'' shall represent any of its truth values. Herein the new predicates evaluate according to the following table: {| class="wikitable" ! ''p'' !! IS TRUE !! IS FALSE !! IS UNKNOWN !!   !! IS NOT TRUE !! IS NOT FALSE !! IS NOT UNKNOWN |- | TRUE || TRUE || FALSE || FALSE || || FALSE || TRUE || TRUE |- | FALSE || FALSE || TRUE || FALSE || || TRUE || FALSE || TRUE |- | UNKNOWN || FALSE || FALSE || TRUE || || TRUE || TRUE || FALSE |} Please notice that all predicates leads to TRUE or FALSE and never to UNKNOWN. === NOT === The next operation is the negation of the new value. To which value evaluates 'NOT UNKNOWN'? The UNKNOWN value represents the impossibility to decide between TRUE and FALSE. It is not feasible that the negation of this impossibility leads to TRUE or FALSE. Likewise it is UNKNOWN. -- Which rows will match? (1) SELECT * FROM t1 WHERE NOT col_2 = NULL; -- 'col_2 = NULL' evaluates to UNKNOWN in all cases, see above. -- Is this SELECT equivalent to the first one? (2) SELECT * FROM t1 EXCEPT SELECT * FROM t1 WHERE col_2 = NULL; -- No, it's different!! Independent from NULL markers in col_2, (1) retrieves -- absolutely NO row and (2) retrieves ALL rows. The above SELECT (1) will retrieve no rows as 'NOT col_2 = NULL' evaluates to the same as 'col_2 = NULL', namely UNKNOWN. And the SELECT (2) will retrieve all rows, as the part after EXCEPT will retrieve no rows, hence only the part before EXCEPT is relevant. In the abstract syntax of logical systems ''p'' shall represent any of its truth values and NOT ''p'' its negation. Herein the following table applies: {| class="wikitable" ! ''p'' !! NOT ''p'' |- | TRUE || FALSE |- | FALSE || TRUE |- | UNKNOWN || UNKNOWN |} === AND, OR === There are the two binary operations AND and OR. They evaluate as follows: {| class="wikitable" ! ''p'' !! ''q'' !! ''p'' AND ''q'' !! ''p'' OR ''q'' |- | TRUE || TRUE || TRUE || TRUE |- | TRUE || FALSE || FALSE || TRUE |- | TRUE || UNKNOWN || UNKNOWN || TRUE |- | FALSE || TRUE || FALSE || TRUE |- | FALSE || FALSE || FALSE || FALSE |- | FALSE || UNKNOWN || FALSE || UNKNOWN |- | UNKNOWN || TRUE || UNKNOWN || TRUE |- | UNKNOWN || FALSE || FALSE || UNKNOWN |- | UNKNOWN || UNKNOWN || UNKNOWN || UNKNOWN |} The precedence of the operations is defined as usual: IS predicate, NOT, AND, OR. == Some Examples == -- -- Add a new row to the test data base INSERT INTO person (id, firstname, lastname) -- Omit some columns to generate NULL markers VALUES (99, 'Tommy', 'Test'); COMMIT; SELECT * FROM person -- focus all tests to the new row WHERE id = 99 -- (1): TRUE AND -- (3): (1) AND (2) ==> TRUE AND UNKNOWN ==> UNKNOWN ( date_of_birth = NULL -- (2): UNKNOWN ); -- no hit SELECT * FROM person WHERE id = 99 -- (1): TRUE AND -- (3): (1) AND (2) ==> TRUE AND TRUE ==> TRUE ( date_of_birth IS NULL -- (2): TRUE ); -- hit SELECT * FROM person WHERE id = 99 -- (1): TRUE OR -- (3): (1) OR (2) ==> TRUE OR UNKNOWN ==> TRUE ( date_of_birth = NULL -- (2): UNKNOWN ); -- hit SELECT * FROM person WHERE id = 99 -- (1): TRUE AND -- (4): (1) AND (3) ==> TRUE AND FALSE ==> FALSE ( NOT -- (3): NOT (2) ==> NOT TRUE ==> FALSE date_of_birth IS NULL -- (2): TRUE ); -- no hit (same as AND date_of_birth IS NOT NULL) -- Clean up the test database DELETE FROM person WHERE id = 99; COMMIT;
{{Java Programming/Navigation|previous=Recursions|next=Transactions}} {{BookCat}}

====Prokofiev==== * 1) Dmaj transfers to some keys that aren't related which is a 20th century technique like the diminished 7th (d-->c) * 2) Amaj which is the dominant of D, it then transfers to the mediant and into the minor submediant which is a 20th c technique * 3) Dmaj * 4)
====Chen Yung==== * 1st movement is in Dmaj * 2nd movement is in Bb Maj * 3rd movement is in Eb maj * 4th movement is in C maj * based on the major pentatonic scale of D {{bookcat}}

== Welcome! ==
[[Wikibooks:Welcome|Welcome]] to Wikibooks, CFernandez!
[[File:Crystal Clear app kedit.png|20px|link=|alt=]] '''First steps tutorial'''
'''Wikibooks is for [[WB:AGF|collaborative]] development of free [[WB:WIW|textbooks]].''' You do not need technical skills to [[Using Wikibooks|contribute]]. You can [[WB:BOLD|easily change most books]]. Please [[WB:CHAT|introduce yourself]], and let us know what [[WB:PROJECTS|interests you]]. If you already contribute at other Wikimedia projects, our [[Wikibooks:Wikibooks for Wikimedians|Wikimedia Orientation]] should quickly get you started.
(Would you like to provide [[Template talk:Bigwelcome|feedback]] on this message?)
[[File:Icon apps query.svg|20px|link=|alt=]] '''Getting help'''
* Read the [[Using Wikibooks]] book for a friendly introduction to the project, or our [[Help:Contents|help pages]] for more information. * You can get friendly help from the community in the [[WB:HELP|user assistance room]] or our [[irc:wikibooks|IRC channel]]. * Upload freely licensed files to [[commons:Wikimedia Commons|Wikimedia Commons]]. You may [[WB:RFP|request permission]] to upload [[w:fair use|fair use]] files locally. Please include author and source {{tl|information}} and a {{nowrap|{{tl|non-free use rationale}}}} for [[WB:FU|non-free]] files.
[[File:Nuvola filesystems trashcan full.png|20px|link=|alt=]] '''Made a mistake?'''
* You can [[WB:REVERT|restore]] a previously saved version. * Pages should follow the [[WB:NP|'''Book Title/Chapter Title''']] naming convention. * Need to rename a page? Use the ''move'' tab (is available once your account is 4 days old - until then, ask for [[WB:HELP|help]]). * To request a page be deleted, add {{tlx|delete|''your reason''}} to the top of the page. * Was a page you made deleted? Please read the [[WB:DP|deletion policy]], and check the [[Special:Log/delete|deletion log]] to find out why. Also check the [[WB:RFD|RFD]] archives if applicable. You can request undeletion at [[WB:RFU]], or ask the administrator who deleted the page.
[[File:Transmission icon.png|20px|link=|alt=]] '''Goodies, tips and tricks'''
* Please fill in [[WB:ES|the edit summary]] and [[WB:PREVIEW|preview]] your edits before saving. * Sign your name on [[WB:TALK|discussion pages]] by typing ~~~~ * User scripts can make many tasks easier. Look at the ''Gadgets'' tab of [[Special:Preferences|''my preferences'']]; check off the boxes for the scripts you want, and hit ''save''!
Thanks, --[[User:Xania|ЗAНИA]] [[Image:Flag_of_Estonia.svg|15px]][[User talk:Xania|talk]] 18:23, 15 May 2014 (UTC)

revision.comment: moved from Nominations page, closed as unsuccessful
revision.text:
== [[Wikijunior:Countries A-Z]] == {{closed|Not successful}} I have been working on this book for quite some time, and although it is not finished, I have decided to nominate it for featured status. The book features a page for each country in the world, with a large photograph of the country surrounded by some other basic information. A good page to look at as an example is [[Wikijunior:Countries A-Z/Belgium|Belgium]]. The fact that it is incomplete is not a bad thing. Because I have designed the book specifically so that expanding it is simple, just a matter of filling in parameters for each country and then selecting an image. The simplicity is achieved through preloading and complex templates. To see what I mean try creating a page. Go to the latest page, [[Wikijunior:Countries A-Z/Honduras]] at the time of writing, and click on the red link in the corner that says the name of the next page (Hungary is next after Honduras). If it isn't red the page has already been created. The following will be preloaded on to the page:
{{hidden|header=Click to show/hide|headerstyle= background: #ccccff; width:75%; |content=

{{Template:Wikijunior:Countries A-Z/Page layout
 |name=
 |native-lang=
 |language=
 |native-name=
 |lang-status=Official
 |map=
 |continent=
 |capital=
 |previous=
 |next=
}}
}}
After the page has been created you will see links that say:
{{hidden|header=Click to show/hide|headerstyle= background: #ccccff; width:75%;|contentstyle=text-align:center; |content= [[{{fullurl:WB:Sandbox|action=edit§ion=new&preload=Template:Wikijunior:Countries_A-Z/Preload/Image}} Add an image]]
([[{{fullurl:WB:Sandbox|action=edit§ion=new&preload=Template:Wikijunior:Countries_A-Z/Preload/Missing_image}} Can't find a good image? Tag this page as missing an image]])}}
Clicking on the "Add an image" link will preload the [[Template:Wikijunior:Countries A-Z/Image]] template on to the page, and all that has to be done is to copy-and-paste the name of the image into the indicated spot.
I have also devised a reader rating/review system for the images. Try this out by clicking the "Rate this image" link near the bottom of the page on the left side.
The use of a "Page layout" template allows easy reformatting of all pages at once, which will save trouble in the long run as there will eventually be over a hundred pages.
Please ask if you have any questions. [[User:Liam987|'''Liam987''']] 18:32, 23 June 2012 (UTC) :This book isn't even half finished so it can't become a featured book.
