page.title: International Postage Meter Stamp Catalog/Vatican City

revision.comment: /* GROUP A: Small upright rectangle with Papal seal at top */ --~~~~
revision.text:
=Vatican City= * The first meter was installed in early 1933 and used by the newspaper I’Illustrazione Vaticana. No other meter was used in the Vatican until 1942. * All Vatican City meter franks contain “POSTE VATICANE”. Town marks contain “CITTA’ DEL VATICANO” or “POSTE VATICANE”. Some town marks also include the postal code or the user's identification at the bottom. * The stamps of are grouped according to the appearance of the frank and usage: :: A – Small upright frank with papal seal at top :: B – Frank with side panels containing three vertical lines :: C – Frank with side panels containing leaf design :: D – Frank with side panels containing non-representational ornaments with blank space above and below :: E – Frank with side panels containing two parallel wavy lines :: F – Scalloped outer frame, without side panels, papal seal at top :: PO – Stamps generated only by meters used in the Vatican Post Office * For specialized information about the meter stamps of the Vatican, see ''Repertorio – Catalogo delle Affrancature Meccaniche della CITTA del VATICANO'', 1998, Barberis, Consolini and Rassu, AICAM Publication no. 201.
---- ==GROUP A: Small upright rectangle with Papal seal at top==

[[File: Vatican stamp type A1.jpg|left|450px]] '''A1. Havas''' (MV), January 1933. [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]][$200] : Frank with single-line simulated perforation border, “POSTE/ VATICANE” at bottom. : TM straight-line at left with “L’ILLVSTRAZIONE/ VATICANA” slogan and 4-digit impression counter number above. : Although the latest date seen is 20 III 35, it is possible the meter was used until the newspaper ceased publication in 1940. : TM: SL : V/F: [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]] ★000 '''NOTE''': Proofs exist dated 31 XII 32. Although scarce they are somewhat more common than properly used stamps on cover. [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]][$100] ---- ==GROUP B: Horizontal frank with simulated perforation outer border and straight-line inner border. Panels at sides contain three vertical lines.==
---- ====Sub-group BA: Side panel lines broken by a circle at center==== ----
[[File: Vatican stamp type BA1A.jpg|left|450px]] [[File: Vatican stamp type BA1B.jpg|left|445px]] '''BA1. Sima''' (MV), 1942. : Frank 30 to 32 mm wide, with single circle town mark about 35 mm to the left. : Slogan between TM and frank. : The entire stamp is contained in a double-lined box. :::::::::::::::::::::: '''A'''. Slogan in center between TM and frank :::::::::::::::::::::: '''B'''. The outer box is deeper and contains a slogan at bottom : TM: SC : V/F: [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]]00.00 [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]][$200] : V/F: [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]]0.000 [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]][One postally used example known, $500. Several proof are known, $200] [[File: Vatican stamp type BA2A.jpg|left|460px]] [[File: Vatican stamp type BA2B.jpg|left|470px]]

'''BA2. Sima''' (MV), 1949. : Very similar to Type BA1 but the frank is wider, ~35 mm. : “POSTE VATICANE” has dots or dashes at the sides. : TM: SC : V/F: [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]]★00.00 (one user known) [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]][$200] : V/F: [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]]★00.= (two users known) [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]][$25] [[File: Vatican stamp type BA3.jpg|left|410px]] [[File: Vatican stamp type BA3aa.jpg|right|410px]] '''BA3. Lirma''' (MV), 1958. [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]][$10] : Very similar to Type BA1 but the distance between the TM and the frank is smaller, ~24-25 mm. : The frank itself is slightly narrower, ~28-29 mm., than BA1, and the value figures are much smaller. : The panel containing “POSTE VATICANE” does not touch the larger section below. : All examples seen have the Papal seal between the TM and frank. :::::::::::::::::: Five users known. :::::::::::::::::: TM: SC :::::::::::::::::: V/F: [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]] [[File: MeterCat 5-point asterisk.jpg|12px]]000 :::::::::::::::::::: '''a'''. With “VIA / AEREA” added below frank [[File: Vatican stamp type BA4.jpg|left|425px]] '''BA4. Lirma''' (MV), 1981. : Very similar to Type BA3 but without the outer box. : Spacing between TM and frank ~30-31 mm. : TM: SC, BIC : V/F: [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]][[File: MeterCat 5-point asterisk.jpg|12px]]000 (two users known.) [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]][$10] : V/F: [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]]00000 (one user known) [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]][$25] [[File: Vatican stamp type BA5.jpg|left|320px]] '''BA5. Lirma''' (MV), 1970. [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]][$10] : Similar to Type BA3 but the TM and frank are narrowly spaced, only 1 to 4 mm apart. : Narrow frank, ~26 mm wide. : The frank displaces the lines of the outer box. : User ID in bottom of TM. : Two users known. : TM: SC : V/F: [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]] [[File: MeterCat 5-point asterisk.jpg|12px]]000 [[File: Vatican stamp type BA6.jpg|left|350px]] '''BA6. Postalia''' (MV), 1986. [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]][$10] : Similar to Type BA5 but the outer box lines are complete and are not broken by the frank. : The value figures are narrow, sanserif. : The bottom of the TM is blank. : Slogan is outside box at left. (''not shown'') : One user known: “PONTIFICIA COMMISSIONE MIGRAZIONI E TURISMO” : V/F: [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]]0000 [[File: Vatican stamp type BA7.jpg|left|320px]] '''BA7. Postalia''' (MV) : As Type BA6 but without greater border around frank and TM. : Reported but not seen by the authors. : The illustration is a retouched photocopy that may not be true in all details. : TM: SC : V/F: [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]]000 [[File: Vatican stamp type BA8.jpg|left|290px]] [[File: Vatican stamp type BA8aa.jpg|right|310px]] '''BA8. Lirma''' (MV), 1983. [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]][$5] : As Type BA5 but without the outer box. : TM: BIC : V/F: [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]] [[File:MeterCat 6-point starburst h.jpg|12px]]000 [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]] [[File:MeterCat 6-point starburst h.jpg|12px]]0000 ::::::::::::::: '''a'''. With Meter ID below frank: “Lmae 404” [[File: Vatican stamp type BA9.jpg|left|290px]] '''BA9'''. Undetermined, probably Audion (MV). : Frank very similar to Type BA8. : “POSTE VATICANE” is sanserif, and the date figures are different. : TM: DC : V/F: [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]] [[File:MeterCat 6-point starburst h.jpg|12px]]0000 [[File: Vatican stamp type BA10.jpg|left|510px]] '''BA10. Francotyp "Cc"''' (MV), 1977. [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]][$5] : Very wide spacing without outer box. : Value figures oval, large and thick. : One user known. : TM: SC : V/F: [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]] ◆000 [[File: Vatican stamp type BA11.jpg|left|435px]]
'''BA11. Audion''' (MV), 1991. : “POSTE VATICANE” sanserif as with Type BA9 but taller. : V/F: [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]]00000 ::::::::::::::::::::: '''a'''. TM and slogan boxed together. [[File: Vatican stamp type BA12.jpg|left|350px]] '''BA12. Francotyp-Postalia''' (MV), 1993. : Wide frank. Panel at top does not have a bottom line completely across the frank. : The lines in the side ornaments are equal in length. : TM: SC : V/F: [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]]00000 [[File: Vatican stamp type BA13.jpg|left|350px]] '''BA13. Neopost “Electronic” ''' (MV), 1999. : Wide frank as with Type BA12, but “POSTE VATICANE” is narrower leaving blank areas at the sides. : The central line of the side ornaments is longer than others. : TM: DC : V/F: [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]]00,00 [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]] ≋0000 [[File: Vatican stamp type BA14.jpg|left|330px]] '''BA14. Neopost ''' (digital). : Relatively narrow frank similar in size to Type BA11. : No panel lines at top or bottom. : The value figures are relatively large and located near the top of the inner box. : The date figures are much smaller than the value figures and located below the center of the town mark. : TM: DC : V/F: [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]]00,00 ---- ====Sub-group BB: Middle side panel line is much thicker than the others==== ----
[[File: Vatican stamp type BB1.jpg|left|430px]] '''BB1. Audion''' (MV), 1987. [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]][$5] : Frank 33 x 28/29 mm. : Spacing very narrow, ~3-4 mm. ::::::::::::::::::::: '''A'''. TM and slogan are contained within a single-line box with rounded corners ::::::::::::::::::::: '''B'''. Without box around TM or slogan : TM: BIC : V/F: [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]]00000 (narrow but thick) ---- ====Sub-group BC: Lines in side panel line continuous, not broken in center==== ----
[[File: Vatican stamp type BC1.jpg|left|290px]] '''BC1. Audion''' (MV), 1988. : Frank nearly square, 27-28 x 26 mm. : TM: BIC : V/F: [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]]00000 ---- ====Sub-group BD: Side panel lines with solid circle in center==== ----
[[File: Vatican stamp type BD1.jpg|left|290px]] '''BD1. Audion “6000” ''' (MV), 1993. : Frank identical to Type BC1 except for the solid circle in the center of the side panels. : One meter in use from 1993 to 1997. : TM: SC : V/F: [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]]00000 ---- ==GROUP C: Franks as Group B but side panels contain leaf design==
---- ====Sub-group CA: Side panel leaves ornate with blank circles at top and bottom==== ----
[[File: Vatican stamp type CA1.jpg|left|370px]] [[File: Vatican stamp type CA1aa.jpg|right|370px]] '''CA1. Postalia''' (MV), 1957. [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]][$10] : Value figures within small box at center. : Narrow spacing between TM and frank, ~1-3 mm. : The entire stamp is contained in a double-lined box. : TM with or without user identification letter at bottom. : TM: SC : V/F: [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]]0000 (narrow sanserif) :::::::::::::::::: '''a'''. With “VIA AREA” above the town mark ---- ====Sub-group CB: Side panel leaves simple with small cross at center==== ----
[[File: Vatican stamp type CB1.jpg|left|430px]] '''CB1. Lirma''' (MV), 1968. [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]][$10] : Similar to Type BA3 but with different side panels. : Frank 27-29 mm wide. [[File: Vatican stamp type CB1 NOTE.jpg|right|300px]] : TM: SC : V/F: [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]] [[File: MeterCat 5-point asterisk.jpg|12px]]000 '''NOTE''': An Italian meter similar to Type CB1 exists but without the outer box. It is easily mistaken for a Vatican stamp because it contains the Papal seal between the TM and frank. [[File: Vatican stamp type CB2.jpg|left|340px]] '''CB2. Postalia''' (MV), 1986. [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]][$5] : Similar to Type CB1 but much narrower spacing between TM and frank. : With slogan at left outside box. (''not shown'') : One user known. : TM: SC : V/F: [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]] [[File: MeterCat 5-point asterisk.jpg|12px]]0000 [[File: Vatican stamp type CB3A.jpg|left|325px]] [[File: Vatican stamp type CB3B.jpg|left|325px]] '''CB3. Lirma''' (MV), 1987. [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]][$5] : Similar to Type CB1 but much narrower spacing between TM and frank, 1 to 3 mm. : No outer box. :::::::::::::::: '''A'''. TM large, ~27 mm :::::::::::::::: '''B'''. TM smaller, ~25 mm, and slightly raised. Frank is taller : V/F: [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]] [[File: MeterCat 5-point asterisk.jpg|12px]]000 [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]] [[File: MeterCat 5-point asterisk.jpg|12px]]0000 ---- ====Sub-group CC: Elaborate leaf and stem structure without breaks in the side panels==== '''NOTE''': See also Types PO1 and PO2 for stamps with this frank design. ----
[[File: Vatican stamp type CC1.jpg|left|320px]] '''CC1. Francotyp''' (MV), 1974. : Tall and narrow lettering of "POSTE VATICANE", with serifs, fills top panel. : Leaf and stem design in side panels leaves little white space. : Narrow spacing between TM and frank. : TM: BIC : V/F: [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]] ◆000.= [[File: Vatican stamp type CC2.jpg|left|355px]] '''CC2. Francopost (Frama “M/E”) ''' (MV), 1994. : The letters of “POSTE VATICANE” are larger than with Type CC1 and without serifs. : The design in the side panels is less elaborate than with CC1 and shows more white space. : TM: SC : V/F: [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]] ★0000 [[File: Vatican stamp type CC3.jpg|left|325px]] '''CC3. Francopost (Frama “MailMax”) ''' (digital), 2005. : Frank narrow than Types CC1 and CC2. : “POSTE VATICANE” is smaller and surrounded by a double inner frame with dots at the sides. : Value figures are quite large. : TM: SC : V/F: [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]]00,00 ---- ====Sub-group CD: Side panel contain four leaves, two above, two below, with nothing at center==== ----
[[File: Vatican stamp type CD1.jpg|left|365px]] '''CD1. Francotyp''' (MV), 1973. [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]][$25] : Side panels contain fancy leaves. : Small single-circle TM with “POSTE VATICANE” at top, blank at bottom. : “VIA AEREA”, 24 mm wide, above TM. : The stamp is contained within a double-lined box. : With slogan below inside box: “L’OSSERVATORE ROMANO” : V/F: [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]][[File: MeterCat 5-point asterisk.jpg|12px]]000 (A) [[File: Vatican stamp type CD2.jpg|left|375px]] '''CD2. Francotyp''' (MV), 1975. [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]][$25] : Very similar to Type CD1 but leaves in side panels are simpler. : “VIA AEREA” above TM is narrower, 16 mm. : TM: SC : V/F: [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]] ◆00 (thick, sanserif oval) [[File: Vatican stamp type CD3.jpg|left|365px]] '''CD3. Postalia''' (MV), 1985. [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]][$5] : Very similar to Type CD1, with fancy leaves, but without “VIA AEREA”. : The TM is slightly larger than with CD1, and the value figures are smaller and narrower. : TM: SC : V/F: [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]]00000 ---- ==GROUP D: The side panels contain a non-representational ornamental design with blank spaces above and below==
[[File: Vatican stamp type D1.jpg|left|430px]] '''D1. Audion''' (MV), 1986. [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]][$5] : Spacing between TM and frank very narrow, ~2-5 mm ::::::::::::::::::::: '''A'''. TM and slogan are contained within a single-line box with rounded corners. TM: SC ::::::::::::::::::::: '''B'''. Without box around TM or slogan. TM: BIC : V/F: [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]]00000 (narrow but heavy) [[File: Vatican stamp type D2.jpg|left|355px]] '''D2. Neopost “Electronic” ''' (MV). [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]][$10] : As Type D1 but frank is not as tall. : “POSTE VATICANE” is narrower. : TM: BIC : V/F: [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]] ≋000 [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]] ≋0000 [[File: Vatican stamp type D3.jpg|left|345px]] '''D3. Pitney Bowes-GB “A900” '''series (MV), 1990. : Frank wider than Types D1 and 2. : TM: SC : V/F: [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]] ≋0000 [[File: Vatican stamp type D4.jpg|left|350px]] '''D4. Pitney Bowes-GB “A900” '''series (MV). : As Type D3 but line under “POSTE VATICANE” extends across the frank. : TM: SC : V/F: [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]] ≋0000 [[File: Vatican stamp type D5.jpg|left|325px]] '''D5. Francopost (Frama “M/E”) ''' (MV). : Frank same size as Type D2 but “POSTE VATICANE” wider with line underneath extending across the frank. : Value figures thick. : TM: SC : V/F: [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]] ★00,00 [[File: Vatican stamp type D6.jpg|left|330px]] '''D6. Francopost (Frama “EPS”) ''' (MV). : As Type D5 but value figures are not as large or thick. : TM: SC : V/F: [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]]00,00 [[File: Vatican stamp type D7.jpg|left|320px]] '''D7'''. Meter model uncertain (MV). : Similar to Type D6 but the frank is smaller and the value figures are quite narrow. : Value box has line at bottom. : TM: SC : V/F: [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]]00,00 ---- ==GROUP E: The side panels contain two parallel wavy lines==
[[File: Vatican stamp type E1.jpg|left|290px]] '''E1. Audion''' (MV), 1988. [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]][$10] : Frank 27/27 x 24 mm. : Spacing very narrow, ~3-4 mm. : TM: SC : V/F: [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]]00000 [[File: Vatican stamp type E2.jpg|left|410px]] '''E2. Audion''' (MV), 1988. : As Type E1 but frank is slightly larger, and “POSTE VATICANE” is taller. : TM and slogan boxed. : TM: BIC : V/F: [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]]00000 ---- ==GROUP F: Scalloped outer frame line, without inner panels. Papal seal at top, “POSTE VATICANE” at bottom==
[[File: Vatican stamp type F1.jpg|left|350px]]
'''F1. Frama “EPS” ''' (MV), 28 January, 2000. : Frank is nearly square. : Four meters placed into use. : TM: SC : V/F: [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]] ★0000 ---- ==GROUP PO: Stamps generated only by meters used in the Vatican Post Office==
[[File: Vatican stamp type PO1.jpg|left|520px]] '''PO1. Hasler''' (MV), 1958. Post Office stamp. : Frank design as in Sub-group CC, with leaf and stem design in the side panels. : “POSTE VATICANE” in top panel has a dot at each side. : Wide spacing between TM and frank, 46-47 mm. : With slogan consisting of the Papal shield centered between the TM and frank. : TM: BIC with “POSTE” at bottom : V/F: [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]] ◆0000.= '''NOTE''': This stamp was cataloged as Type CC1 in the original paper version of this catalog. [[File: Vatican stamp type PO2.jpg|left|400px]] '''PO2. Francotyp''' (MV), 2 February 1969. [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]][$500] : As with Type PO1 the frank resembles Sub-group CC stamps. : Small frank, 28 x 21 mm. : Box containing registration number between TM and frank. : Used for one month only, February 1969, and used only on registered mail. [[File: Vatican stamp type PO2 receipt.jpg|right|400px]] :::::::::::::::::: TM: BIC with “POSTE” at bottom. :::::::::::::::::: V/F: [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]] ★★★00.= '''NOTES''': * Stamps of this design without a frame around the value figures are receipts. * This stamp was cataloged as Type CC2 in the original paper version of this catalog. ----
'''NOTE''': In addition to actual postage meters the newspaper L’Osservatore Romano used preprinted indicia that resemble meter stamps. They are found with date and postage value added by machine printer and also without the date and/or postage. Examples are shown below. [[File: Vatican pre-printed meter-like stamps.jpg|center|550px]] ---- ----
Return to main catalog ⇒ [[../]]
Return to top ⇒ [http://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/International_Postage_Meter_Stamp_Catalog/Vatican_City Vatican_City] ----

== Welcome! ==
[[Wikibooks:Welcome|Welcome]] to Wikibooks, Jtk113!
[[File:Crystal Clear app kedit.png|20px|link=|alt=]] '''First steps tutorial'''
'''Wikibooks is for [[WB:AGF|collaborative]] development of free [[WB:WIW|textbooks]].''' You do not need technical skills to [[Using Wikibooks|contribute]]. You can [[WB:BOLD|easily change most books]]. Please [[WB:CHAT|introduce yourself]], and let us know what [[WB:PROJECTS|interests you]]. If you already contribute at other Wikimedia projects, our [[Wikibooks:Wikibooks for Wikimedians|Wikimedia Orientation]] should quickly get you started.
(Would you like to provide [[Template talk:Bigwelcome|feedback]] on this message?)
[[File:Icon apps query.svg|20px|link=|alt=]] '''Getting help'''
* Read the [[Using Wikibooks]] book for a friendly introduction to the project, or our [[Help:Contents|help pages]] for more information. * You can get friendly help from the community in the [[WB:HELP|user assistance room]] or our [[irc:wikibooks|IRC channel]]. * Upload freely licensed files to [[commons:Wikimedia Commons|Wikimedia Commons]]. You may [[WB:RFP|request permission]] to upload [[w:fair use|fair use]] files locally. Please include author and source {{tl|information}} and a {{nowrap|{{tl|non-free use rationale}}}} for [[WB:FU|non-free]] files.
[[File:Nuvola filesystems trashcan full.png|20px|link=|alt=]] '''Made a mistake?'''
* You can [[WB:REVERT|restore]] a previously saved version. * Pages should follow the [[WB:NP|'''Book Title/Chapter Title''']] naming convention. * Need to rename a page? Use the ''move'' tab (is available once your account is 4 days old - until then, ask for [[WB:HELP|help]]). * To request a page be deleted, add {{tlx|delete|''your reason''}} to the top of the page. * Was a page you made deleted? Please read the [[WB:DP|deletion policy]], and check the [[Special:Log/delete|deletion log]] to find out why. Also check the [[WB:RFD|RFD]] archives if applicable. You can request undeletion at [[WB:RFU]], or ask the administrator who deleted the page.
[[File:Transmission icon.png|20px|link=|alt=]] '''Goodies, tips and tricks'''
* Please fill in [[WB:ES|the edit summary]] and [[WB:PREVIEW|preview]] your edits before saving. * Sign your name on [[WB:TALK|discussion pages]] by typing ~~~~ * User scripts can make many tasks easier. Look at the ''Gadgets'' tab of [[Special:Preferences|''my preferences'']]; check off the boxes for the scripts you want, and hit ''save''!
Thanks, --[[User:Xania|ЗAНИA]] [[Image:Flag_of_the_Isle_of_Mann.svg|15px]][[User talk:Xania|talk]] 18:35, 4 June 2014 (UTC)

page.title: User:Saltrabook/60 hours practical research course for health professionals

revision.comment: Removing "Program_research_course.png", it has been deleted from Commons by [[commons:User:Denniss|Denniss]] because: Out of [[commons:COM:PS|project scope]]: [[commons:COM:ADVERT|promotional content]].
revision.text:
https://www.dropbox.com/s/f85yqwbsq3vhuqg/Research%20course%20health%20professional%20.docx
=='''Type of course:''' University Post graduate semi-virtual program on practical research - Diploma (6 credits)== =='''Participant universities''':Universities with occupational, environmental and public health training courses== =='''Participant students''': Professionals who work in a clinic with the possibility to collect patient questionnaires & Professionals in public health with access to register data== =='''Objectives:''' to perform practical research course based on a ready questionnaire or register data== =='''Time schedule:''' 60 hours distributed over 6 month:== 24 hours in 3 workshops a 8 hours + 8 hours used for 3 month data collecting + 28 hours at home in 2 months to analyse the data and to write a small article =='''Teachers:''' a team of 2-5 will give the lectures and continue as the tutors to inspire and help during the data collection and writing of the article== =='''Finansial:''' Saltra Panama Teaching Fund:== The students fee = 50-100 USD. The teachers are paid the costs for travel and hotel if outside the City =='''After the course''': - the participants will be able to:== # Perform minor research projects with their own research questions # Prepare a minor article for publication in “La revista…” # Be active members of the Panama Collegium Ramazinni (PRC) # Continue to develop their research skills # Be active teachers in the courses # Be active participants in the PCR meeting and give lectures on research methods and present their own research =='''Content'''==
===Workshop 1=== ==== [[/Formulating a good research question/]] ==== ==== [[/Zotero: collect, organise and cite lit./]] ==== ==== [[/Make your own archive en Dropbox/]] ==== ==== [[/Search and organise the literature/]] ==== ==== [[/Write a study protocol/]] ==== ==== [[/Learn to use Epi-data/]] ====
===Workshop 2=== ==== [[/Analyse your own data/]] ==== ==== [[/Excel,Epi-info, Epi-analysis /]] ==== ==== [[/Scientific communication IMRAD/]] ====
==== [[/Write your own article/]] ==== ==== [[/Evaluation of the course/]] ====
===Workshop 3===
==== [[/Make the article read to Publish in “La Revista…”/]] ==== ==== [[/Diploma and the rights to be member of the Panama Collegium Ramazinni/]] ==== ==== [[/Panama Collegium Ramazinni/]] ==== ==== [[/List of members of Panama Collegium Ramazinni/]] ====
=='''Download the program here:'''== https://www.dropbox.com/s/f85yqwbsq3vhuqg/Research%20course%20health%20professional%20.docx

page.title: How to Ace FYLSE/2013 F Q4

revision.text:
http://admissions.calbar.ca.gov/Portals/4/documents/gbx/July2013CBX%20SelectedAnswers%20Essay1-6_R.pdf
==Fact Summary== D dumped trees on P's property which caused flooding of P's property and chattel. It costs 30K to remove the tree, lowered the property value by 10k and costs 4k to buy or 5k to fix the chattel. ==Comments== * This is an intentional Torts and their remedies question. ==Outline [P v. D]== ===Trespass to Land=== * Licensee * Consent * necessity ====Legal Remedies==== =====Damages===== * actual cause * proximate * certain and ascertainable * mitigation =====Nominal damages===== =====Actual damages===== * Diminution in value. * Cost of repair: removal of the trees. =====Punitive damages===== =====Special damages===== =====Restitution===== =====Ejectment=====
====Equitable Remedies==== * Inadequate Legal Remedy * Balancing hardships * No defenses (i.e. laches) =====Injunction===== ===Trespass to Chattel=== * transferred intent ===Conversion=== ====Restitutionary Money Judgment==== * Ejectment * Injunction * Feasibility * Hardships

page.title: How to Ace FYLSE/2011 F Q4

revision.text:
http://admissions.calbar.ca.gov/LinkClick.aspx?fileticket=bh5Y-xQTGA0%3d&tabid=2348 ==Fact Summary== G, a student, left the school while unsupervised and went to F to work for money. While working and in a hurry, G hit and injured P. P's husband H came to see P and was shocked and suffered an injury.
==Outline== ===Q1=== ====P v. G==== =====Negligence===== * Duty: foreseeable plaintiff * Breach * Causation * Damage =====Defenses===== * Fireman's Rule ====P v. F==== =====Negligence===== * Respondeat superior: employee v. independent contractor * Duty: foreseeable plaintiff * Breach * Causation * Damage =====Defenses===== ====P v. SD==== =====Negligence===== * Respondeat superior: employee v. independent contractor * Duty * Breach * Causation * Damage =====Defenses===== ===Q2=== ====H v.G==== =====NIED===== * Negligent Conduct * In Plaintiff's Presence * Physical Symptoms

page.title: How to Ace FYLSE/2010 J Q1

revision.text: http://admissions.calbar.ca.gov/Portals/4/documents/gbx/1007_Essay_Selected-Answers.pdf ==Fact summary== B stole H's gun which was not secured as required by law and use it to attack P in a parking lot owned by C who had similar incidents before but did nothing. P fainted and suffered injuries. ==Outline== ===P v. H=== ====Negligence==== ====Duty==== # Standard of Care # Negligence per se ====Breach==== ====Causation==== # Actual # Proximate ====Damages==== ====Defenses==== # Assumption of Risk # Comparative Negligence # Contributory Negligence ===P v. B=== ====Assault==== ====Battery==== ====IIED==== ====NIED==== ====Conversion/Trespass to Chattel==== ====False Imprisonment==== ===P v. C=== ====Negligence==== Duty, Breach, Causation, Proximate Cause

revision.comment: Created page with "Patty is in the business of transporting human organs for transplant in City. She is paid only upon timely delivery of a viable organ; the delay of an hour can make an organ n..."
revision.text: Patty is in the business of transporting human organs for transplant in City. She is paid only upon timely delivery of a viable organ; the delay of an hour can make an organ nonviable. David transports gasoline over long distances in a tank truck. Recently, he was hauling gasoline through City. As David was crossing a bridge in City, his truck skidded on an oily patch and became wedged across the roadway, blocking all traffic in both directions for two hours. Patty was delivering a kidney and was on the bridge several cars behind David when the accident occurred. The traffic jam caused Patty to be two hours late in making her delivery and made the kidney nonviable. Consequently, she was not paid the $1,000 fee she would otherwise have received. Patty contacted Art, a lawyer, and told him that she wanted to sue David for the loss of her fee. “There isn’t a lot of money involved,” she said, “but I want to teach David a lesson. David can’t possibly afford the legal fees to defend this case, so maybe we can put him out of business.” Art agreed and, concluding that he could not prove negligence against David, decided that the only plausible claim would be one based on strict liability for ultrahazardous activity. Art filed a suit based on that theory against David on behalf of Patty, seeking recovery of damages to cover the $1,000 fee Patty lost. The facts recited in the first three paragraphs above appeared on the face of the complaint. David filed a motion to dismiss. The court granted the motion on the grounds that the complaint failed to state a cause of action and that, in any event, the damages alleged were not recoverable. It entered judgment in David’s favor. David then filed suit against Patty and Art for malicious prosecution. 1. Did the court correctly grant David’s motion to dismiss on the grounds stated? Discuss. 2. What is the likely outcome of David’s suit for malicious prosecution against Patty and Art? Discuss.

Hello. I am a user catalan, born in Barcelona but currently reside in Madrid (I do not like football or politics xD). In Wikipedia in spanish I make all sorts of tasks, from creating, translating or perfection articles even the most basic maintenance. I also have a mentoring program where I try to help novice users and my main hobbies are <s>sleeping</s> architecture and astronomy.
I have thousands of followers on social networks, but no one gives me money so, sadly, I have to keep working (I'm very lazy) :/
Not wanting to work more (did I say that I'm very lazy?) add [[w:es:Usuario:Rauletemunoz|this link]] to my user page in spanish and you do everything else.

revision.comment: /* GROUP A: Stamps for private and commercial use, inscribed “CORREOS” */
revision.text:
=Venezuela= * The first meter was installed in 1950. * All franks are inscribed “VENEZUELA”. * Most stamps show a License number (L#) rather than a Meter number (M#). * The stamps are grouped according to appearance and function as follows: :: A - Commercial use designs, inscribed “CORREOS” :: B - Commercial use designs, inscribed “IPOSTEL” :: OO - Official government use
---- ==GROUP A: Stamps for private and commercial use, inscribed “CORREOS”==
[[File: Venezuela stamp type A1.jpg|left|270px]] '''A1. Pitney Bowes “R” ''' (MV), 1950. : Horizontal design incorporating TM. : Inscribed “EEUU DE VENEZUELA/ CORREOS” across top. : Horse design between TM and value box. : L# with “LIC.—“ prefix and “-P.B.” suffix. : TM: SC : V/F: [[File: MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]] ≋00 : [[File: Venezuela stamp type A2.jpg|left|280px]] '''A2. Pitney Bowes “R” ''' (MV). : As Type A1 but inscribed “REPUBLICA DE VENEZUELA/ CORREOS” at top. :::::::::::::: '''A'''. L# with “LIC.—“ prefix and “-P.B.” suffix :::::::::::::: '''B'''. L# with “MH.—“ prefix and “-P.B.” suffix : TM: SC : V/F: [[File: MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]] ≋00 : [[File: Venezuela stamp type A3.jpg|left|280px]] '''A3. Pitney Bowes “5000” ''' (MV). [[File: MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]][$5] : Similar to Type A2, but value box is wider. : L# with “LIC.” prefix and “P.B.” suffix. : TM: SC : V/F: [[File: MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]] ≋.00 [[File: MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]] ≋0.00 [[File: Venezuela stamp type A4.jpg|left|325px]] '''A4. Pitney Bowes-GB “5000” ''' (MV). : Similar to Type A3 but country inscription starts right of the town mark and extends beyond the right side of the value box. : L# with “LIC.” prefix and “P.B.” suffix. : TM: DC : V/F: [[File: MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]] ≋0.00 [[File: Venezuela stamp type A5.jpg|left|320px]] '''A5. Pitney Bowes-GB “6300” ''' (MV). : Similar to Type A4 but “CORREOS” is below the value box, and the date and value figures are on the same level. : L# below “CORREOS” with “LIC.” prefix and “P.B.” suffix. : TM: DC : V/F: [[File: MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]] ≋0.00 [[File: Venezuela stamp type A6.jpg|left|340px]] '''A6. Pitney Bowes-GB “Automax” ''' (MV). : Frank with single, simulated perforation border line. : Country name in curved panel at top. “CORREOS” in panel at bottom with “BOLIVARES” and M# above. : L# with “P.B.” prefix. : TM: DC, BIC (''one meter only with TM BIC, M# 881'') : V/F: [[File: MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]]=0.oo [[File: Venezuela stamp type A7.jpg|left|345px]] '''A7. Francotyp “Cc/Ccm” ''' (MV). : Upright frank with simulated perforation outer border and straight-line inner border. : “BOLIVARES” above “CORREOS” in scroll at bottom. : Meter model “FRANCOTYP CCM” above L# with “SERIAL” prefix below TM. : TM: DC : V/F: [[File: MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]]0,00 [[File: MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]]◆0,00 ::::::::::::::::: '''a'''. Without “BOLIVARES” [[File: MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]][$5] [[File: Venezuela stamp type A8A.jpg|left|340px]] [[File: Venezuela stamp type A8B.jpg|left|340px]]

'''A8. Hasler “F88” ''' (MV). : Upright frank with double, straight-line frame. : Country name in scroll at top. : Ornamental design above value figures. : L# with “H (circled) HASLER” prefix below frank. : Spacing between TM and frank variable. ::::::::::::::::: '''A'''. “Bs.” right of value figures ::::::::::::::::: '''B'''. “Bs.” left of value figures : TM: SC, DC : V/F: [[File: MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]]0,oo [[File: MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]] ✳0,oo [[File: MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]] ◇0,oo ::::::::::::::::: '''a'''. == Welcome! ==
[[Wikibooks:Welcome|Welcome]] to Wikibooks, Dwyerswimmer06!
[[File:Crystal Clear app kedit.png|20px|link=|alt=]] '''First steps tutorial'''
'''Wikibooks is for [[WB:AGF|collaborative]] development of free [[WB:WIW|textbooks]].''' You do not need technical skills to [[Using Wikibooks|contribute]]. You can [[WB:BOLD|easily change most books]]. Please [[WB:CHAT|introduce yourself]], and let us know what [[WB:PROJECTS|interests you]]. If you already contribute at other Wikimedia projects, our [[Wikibooks:Wikibooks for Wikimedians|Wikimedia Orientation]] should quickly get you started.
(Would you like to provide [[Template talk:Bigwelcome|feedback]] on this message?)
[[File:Icon apps query.svg|20px|link=|alt=]] '''Getting help'''
* Read the [[Using Wikibooks]] book for a friendly introduction to the project, or our [[Help:Contents|help pages]] for more information. * You can get friendly help from the community in the [[WB:HELP|user assistance room]] or our [[irc:wikibooks|IRC channel]]. * Upload freely licensed files to [[commons:Wikimedia Commons|Wikimedia Commons]]. You may [[WB:RFP|request permission]] to upload [[w:fair use|fair use]] files locally. Please include author and source {{tl|information}} and a {{nowrap|{{tl|non-free use rationale}}}} for [[WB:FU|non-free]] files.
[[File:Nuvola filesystems trashcan full.png|20px|link=|alt=]] '''Made a mistake?'''
* You can [[WB:REVERT|restore]] a previously saved version. * Pages should follow the [[WB:NP|'''Book Title/Chapter Title''']] naming convention. * Need to rename a page? Use the ''move'' tab (is available once your account is 4 days old - until then, ask for [[WB:HELP|help]]). * To request a page be deleted, add {{tlx|delete|''your reason''}} to the top of the page. * Was a page you made deleted? Please read the [[WB:DP|deletion policy]], and check the [[Special:Log/delete|deletion log]] to find out why. Also check the [[WB:RFD|RFD]] archives if applicable. You can request undeletion at [[WB:RFU]], or ask the administrator who deleted the page.
[[File:Transmission icon.png|20px|link=|alt=]] '''Goodies, tips and tricks'''
* Please fill in [[WB:ES|the edit summary]] and [[WB:PREVIEW|preview]] your edits before saving. * Sign your name on [[WB:TALK|discussion pages]] by typing ~~~~ * User scripts can make many tasks easier. Look at the ''Gadgets'' tab of [[Special:Preferences|''my preferences'']]; check off the boxes for the scripts you want, and hit ''save''!
Thanks, --[[User:Xania|ЗAНИA]] [[Image:Flag_of_the_Isle_of_Mann.svg|15px]][[User talk:Xania|talk]] 18:19, 5 June 2014 (UTC)

page.title: User:Saltrabook/60 hours practical research course for health professionals/Zotero: collect, organise and cite lit.

revision.text: '''Zotero''' es una extensión libre para el navegador Firefox, que permite a los usuarios recolectar, administrar y citar trabajos de investigación de todo tipo de orígenes desde el navegador. Descripción Con un solo clic de ratón puedes recopilar todos los datos de los principales recursos de información para mantener una biblioteca personal bien organizada. Esta información la podemos utilizar posteriormente para citar en los trabajos de investigación o elaborar bibliografías en los formatos de estilo y documentales más reconocidos. Zotero destaca ante todo por la facilidad de manejo, y las posibilidades de la herramienta tanto on line como off line, permitiéndonos disponer de los documentos y la bibliografía incluso aunque no tengamos conexión a Internet; o trabajar con nuestra bibliografía desde cualquier ordenador sin necesidad de tener una copia de la base de datos. Cause content The cause will last about 2 hours in total. The participants need to download the program ”Zotero for Firefox” on their laptop together with the Firefox browser and the Word text program before the module and bring the laptop to the module . The participants need some knowledge of how research, citation and bibliographies work. We recommend that the partcipants are familiar with the Zotero Guide before the module http://sharonhoward.org/zoterowiki/Main/ResourceNotes and take a glance at the content Aims of the module : Participants will learn how to effectively search and manage store their literature Format: Hands-on classroom teaching

page.title: User:Saltrabook/60 hours practical research course for health professionals/Formulating a good research question

revision.comment: Created page with "'''A Good Research Question''' ‘A research project should in some way enlarge our understanding of a subject or problem. In simple terms, research is about asking a good que..."
revision.text: '''A Good Research Question''' ‘A research project should in some way enlarge our understanding of a subject or problem. In simple terms, research is about asking a good question, finding an answer, and arguing your case.’ Your research hinges on a good question. A good idea and a good interest is not enough. ‘Without the articulation of a good question you are travelling blind’ (O’Leary 2010:47) A dissertation

page.title: User:Saltrabook/60 hours practical research course for health professionals/Make your own archive en Dropbox

revision.comment: Created page with " '''Dropbox''' is a file hosting service operated by Dropbox, Inc., headquartered in San Francisco, California, that offers cloud storage, file synchronization, personal cl..."
revision.text:
'''Dropbox''' is a file hosting service operated by Dropbox, Inc., headquartered in San Francisco, California, that offers cloud storage, file synchronization, personal cloud, and client software. Dropbox allows users to create a special folder on each of their computers, which Dropbox then synchronizes so that it appears to be the same folder (with the same contents) regardless of which computer is used to view it. Files placed in this folder also are accessible through a website and mobile phone applications.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dropbox_%28service%29

This classic Tuna Salad recipe is from the 1940's U.S.
==Ingredients== *1 can (9½­ oz. or 6 ­oz.( ~270g to ~170g)) tuna *¼ apple, finely chopped *½ stalk celery, finely chopped *¼ cup mayonnaise (low fat can work.) *1 tsp. lemon juice *½ chopped green onion or ½ tsp dried chopped white or yellow onion *1 hard boiled egg, chopped (or two hard boiled egg whites and a bit of oil olive oil to make up the difference) *ground black pepper to taste
==Procedure== #Drain and squeeze tuna dry, discarding liquid or reserving for some other use. #Mix all ingredients. #Refrigerate 1 hour or more. #Sprinkle with paprika and trim with lettuce, if desired.

revision.comment: Created page with "== Balanced processing (alpha = 0.81) == === Description === Scales were developed and validated for four dimensions of authentic leadership: Handbook of Management Scales/..."
revision.text:
== Balanced processing (alpha = 0.81) == === Description ===
Scales were developed and validated for four dimensions of authentic leadership: [[Handbook of Management Scales/Self-awareness|self-awareness]], [[Handbook of Management Scales/Relational transparency|relational transparency]], [[Handbook of Management Scales/Internalized moral perspective|internalized moral perspective]], balanced processing.
=== Definition ===
The authors define authentic leadership as "a pattern of leader behavior that draws upon and promotes both positive psychological capacities and a positive ethical climate, to foster greater self-awareness, an internalized moral perspective, balanced processing of information, and relational transparency on the part of leaders working with followers, fostering positive self-development".
Balanced processing refers to "leaders who show that they objectively analyze all relevant data before coming to a decision".
=== Items ===
*Solicits views that challenge his or her deeply held positions. *Listens carefully to different points of view before coming to conclusions.
The authors reported two sample items of this scale only.
=== Source ===
*[http://dx.doi.org/10.1177/0149206307308913 Walumbwa et al. (2008): Authentic Leadership: Development and Validation of a Theory-Based Measure? Journal of Management, Vol. 34, No. 1, pp. 89–126]
=== Related Scales ===
*[[Handbook of Management Scales/Self-awareness|Self-awareness]] *[[Handbook of Management Scales/Relational transparency|Relational transparency]] *[[Handbook of Management Scales/Internalized moral perspective|Internalized moral perspective]]
{{BookCat}}

page.title: Handbook of Management Scales/Internalized moral perspective

revision.comment: Created page with "== Internalized moral perspective (alpha = 0.76) == === Description === Scales were developed and validated for four dimensions of authentic leadership: Handbook of Managem..."
revision.text:
== Internalized moral perspective (alpha = 0.76) == === Description ===
Scales were developed and validated for four dimensions of authentic leadership: [[Handbook of Management Scales/Self-awareness|self-awareness]], [[Handbook of Management Scales/Relational transparency|relational transparency]], internalized moral perspective, [[Handbook of Management Scales/Balanced processing|balanced processing]].
=== Definition ===
The authors define authentic leadership as "a pattern of leader behavior that draws upon and promotes both positive psychological capacities and a positive ethical climate, to foster greater self-awareness, an internalized moral perspective, balanced processing of information, and relational transparency on the part of leaders working with followers, fostering positive self-development".
Internalized moral perspective refers to "an internalized and integrated form of self-regulation".
=== Items ===
*Demonstrates beliefs that are consistent with actions. *Makes decisions based on his/her core beliefs.
The authors reported two sample items of this scale only.
=== Source ===
*[http://dx.doi.org/10.1177/0149206307308913 Walumbwa et al. (2008): Authentic Leadership: Development and Validation of a Theory-Based Measure? Journal of Management, Vol. 34, No. 1, pp. 89–126]
=== Related Scales ===
*[[Handbook of Management Scales/Self-awareness|Self-awareness]] *[[Handbook of Management Scales/Relational transparency|Relational transparency]] *[[Handbook of Management Scales/Balanced processing|Balanced processing]]
{{BookCat}}

revision.comment: Created page with "== Relational transparency (alpha = 0.87) == === Description === Scales were developed and validated for four dimensions of authentic leadership: Handbook of Management Sca..."
revision.text:
== Relational transparency (alpha = 0.87) == === Description ===
Scales were developed and validated for four dimensions of authentic leadership: [[Handbook of Management Scales/Self-awareness|self-awareness]], relational transparency, [[Handbook of Management Scales/Internalized moral perspective|internalized moral perspective]], [[Handbook of Management Scales/Balanced processing|balanced processing]].
=== Definition ===
The authors define authentic leadership as "a pattern of leader behavior that draws upon and promotes both positive psychological capacities and a positive ethical climate, to foster greater self-awareness, an internalized moral perspective, balanced processing of information, and relational transparency on the part of leaders working with followers, fostering positive self-development".
Relational transparency refers to "presenting one’s authentic self (as opposed to a fake or distorted self) to others".
=== Items ===
*Says exactly what he or she means. *Is willing to admit mistakes when they are made.
The authors reported two sample items of this scale only.
=== Source ===
*[http://dx.doi.org/10.1177/0149206307308913 Walumbwa et al. (2008): Authentic Leadership: Development and Validation of a Theory-Based Measure? Journal of Management, Vol. 34, No. 1, pp. 89–126]
=== Related Scales ===
*[[Handbook of Management Scales/Self-awareness|Self-awareness]] *[[Handbook of Management Scales/Internalized moral perspective|Internalized moral perspective]] *[[Handbook of Management Scales/Balanced processing|Balanced processing]]
{{BookCat}}

revision.comment: Created page with "== Self-awareness (alpha = 0.92) == === Description === Scales were developed and validated for four dimensions of authentic leadership: self-awareness, Handbook of Managem..."
revision.text:
== Self-awareness (alpha = 0.92) == === Description ===
Scales were developed and validated for four dimensions of authentic leadership: self-awareness, [[Handbook of Management Scales/Relational transparency|relational transparency]], [[Handbook of Management Scales/Internalized moral perspective|internalized moral perspective]], [[Handbook of Management Scales/Balanced processing|balanced processing]].
=== Definition ===
The authors define authentic leadership as "a pattern of leader behavior that draws upon and promotes both positive psychological capacities and a positive ethical climate, to foster greater self-awareness, an internalized moral perspective, balanced processing of information, and relational transparency on the part of leaders working with followers, fostering positive self-development".
Self-awareness refers to "demonstrating an understanding of how one derives and makes meaning of the world and how that meaning making process impacts the way one views himself or herself over time".
=== Items ===
*Seeks feedback to improve interactions with others. *Accurately describes how others view his or her capabilities.
The authors reported two sample items of this scale only.
=== Source ===
*[http://dx.doi.org/10.1177/0149206307308913 Walumbwa et al. (2008): Authentic Leadership: Development and Validation of a Theory-Based Measure? Journal of Management, Vol. 34, No. 1, pp. 89–126]
=== Related Scales ===
*[[Handbook of Management Scales/Relational transparency|Relational transparency]] *[[Handbook of Management Scales/Internalized moral perspective|Internalized moral perspective]] *[[Handbook of Management Scales/Balanced processing|Balanced processing]]
{{BookCat}}

{{Java Programming/Navigation|previous=SQL: The Standard ISO IEC 9075 and various Implementations|next=Snippets}}
SQL consists of statements which start with a key word like SELECT, DELETE or CREATE and terminate with a semicolon. Their elements are case-insensitive with the exception of fixed character string values like 'Mr. Brown'. [[File:SQL ANATOMY wiki.svg|frame|left|An example of a complete statement with several of its language elements.]]
* ''Clauses'': Statements are subdivided into clauses. The most popular one is the WHERE clause. * ''Predicates'': Predicates specify conditions which can be evaluated to a boolean value. E.g.: a boolean comparison, BETWEEN, LIKE, IS NULL, IN, SOME/ANY, ALL, EXISTS. * ''Expressions'': Expressions are numeric or string values by itself, or the result of arithmetic or concatenation operators, or the result of functions. * ''Object names'': Names of database objects like tables, views, columns, functions. * ''Values'': Numeric or string values. * ''Arithmetic operators'': The plus sign, minus sign, asterisk and solidus (+, –, * and /) specify addition, subtraction, multiplication and division. * ''Concatenation operator'': The '||' sign specifies the concatenation of character strings. * ''Comparison operators'': The equals operator, not equals operator, less than operator, greater than operator, less than or equals operator, greater than or equals operator ( =, <>, <, >, <=, >= ) compares values and expressions. * ''Boolean operators'': AND, OR, NOT combines boolean values.
{{Java Programming/Navigation|previous=SQL: The Standard ISO IEC 9075 and various Implementations|next=Snippets}} {{BookCat}}

Gameplay3d is a '''free''' and '''open-source''' C++/Lua programming framework which makes programming cross-platform games easier by handling many of the tasks which are common to all games, as well as providing a powerful library of classes. It supports both 3D and 2D and can be used to make games on the following platforms: * Microsoft Windows * Apple MacOS X * Linux * Apple iOS * Google Android * BlackBerry This guide will begin by introducing you to gameplay3d, before delving more deeply into its many features. Clear step-by-step examples will be provided, along with code samples which can be tailored towards your own projects. Visit the official gameplay3d website at '''http://www.gameplay3d.org/''' {{Book Search}} === Table of contents === #[[/Getting Started/]]
#[[/An Overview of the Game Class/]]
#[[/gameplay3d Design Concepts/]]

#[[/Scripting with Lua/]]
#[[/Working with 2D/]]
#[[/Tips for optimizing performance/]]
#[[/Links to other useful resources/]]

This page and sub pages are for me to put together draft material, that may or may not come to anything.
I am interested in General Relativity. I am not an expert and the sub pages below are my gradual and hard one efforts to gain an understanding of GR, for the fun of it.
* [[User:Thepigdog/General Relativity - 01 - Shadows of reality|General Relativity - 01 - Shadows of reality]] * [[User:Thepigdog/General Relativity - 02 - Lorentz transforms|General Relativity - 02 - Lorentz transforms]] * [[User:Thepigdog/General Relativity - 02 - Contra variant tensors|General Relativity - 03 - Contra variant tensors]]
* [[User:Thepigdog/Play]] * [[User:Thepigdog/Play2]] * [[User:Thepigdog/Play3]]

revision.comment: /* Distance and the constant speed of light */
revision.text:
The average person can understand General Relativity. Some of the ideas are actually quite simple, even if the details are complex. The key ideas are,
* Invariance * Curvature
Invariance is the idea that a quantity, from the real world will have a value that does not depend on how we measure it. This is an abstract idea, but a fairly simple one.
The other idea is curvature. For curvature think of a sphere, like the world we live on. The surface of the sphere is curved. This is easy to picture. The essence of General Relativity is that curvature is the source of gravity, and that mass creates curvature.
This is hard to picture. A couple of points to clarify. The curvature being discussed is intrinsic curvature. It is the distortions that appear when you are actually in the dimension. In the example given with the sphere it is the distortions the ant would see walking on the sphere. Here the surface is 2 dimensional. But for General Relativity the curvature is in a 4 dimensional space (3 dimensions of space and one of time). General Relativity says that this universe we live in is curved by mass, causing gravity.
When we think of curvature we think of the surface of an object being curved. We can see that the surface is curved from outside. But mathematics allows the curvature to be detected from within the space, by measuring distances and angles. This is the curvature described by General Relativity.
This is hard for anyone to understand physically. But is is easy to see that the sphere is curved, and by analogy we can think about the universe being curved.
Curvature will be dealt with later. Lets start with looking at invariance.
==Shadows of reality==
We perceive the world through our senses. It is always tempting to think that what we sense is actually reality, but it is not. What we think of as reality is an interpretation of the data we receive through our senses.
The way we come to this interpretation is through learning. Learning is finding simpler and simpler models of our world that are consistent with the data provided by our senses.
What we aim to do is to discover the fundamental reality of the world, as facts about the world that are always true.
Consider the sense of vision. It is not a 3 dimensional sense. It is a 2 dimensional grid of pixels received through the camera lens of our eyes. Out of this 2 dimensional world we form our 3 dimensional world model.
My aim is to take you back to this 2 dimensional world and show you how the 3 dimensional world emerges out of it by considering invariance. Then when later I claim that time is simply another dimension which emerges by considering another invariance, it will not seem so shocking.
Our eyesight is complicated by problems of perspective that complicate the matter unnecessarily. Consider instead instead shadows cast by objects from a light source very far away (e.g. the sun). Ignore the complications of the fussy edges of shadows. Lets pretend that the shadows have crisp edges. They are ideal shadows.
==The shadow box==
There is a shadow box. We do not see directly inside the box. We only see the shadows of the objects inside the box.
The box has two buttons that rotate the objects. One button rotates the objects that go around in circles on the screen. One rotates them so that they appear to tumble over each other.
[[File:General relativity - 01 - right triangle.png|200px|right|The shadow of an object whose shadow appears as a right triangle.]] By chance (or authors caprice) one object appears as a right angle triangle with a point at the center of rotation. As the button that rotates the object around the center is pushed we see the triangle rotate around the center. Using a ruler the lengths of the sides of the triangle could be measured in each position. The lengths of the sides do not change. They are invariant.
The concept of angle may then be introduced. The angles at the corners of the triangle are defined to be the same if the ratio of the lengths of the sides is the same.
[[File:General relativity - 01 - pythagorous.png|200px|right|The right triangle rotated, demonstrating Pythagorous.theorem]] By considering similar triangles, this leads to [[w:Pythagorous theorem|Pythagorous theorem]]. By considering the ratios of sides, :<math> rac{A}{C}  rac{A}{C} +  rac{B}{C}  rac{B}{C} = 1</math> or, :<math>A^2 + B^2 = C^2</math>
Pythagorous Theorem may then be used to give a measure of the distance between any two points in a co-ordinate system. A co-ordinate system is a way of identifying positions on the screen, by laying out a grid of parallel lines at right angles to the axis. Positions on the axis are then numbered with. A pair of numbers then identifies a position on the screen, :<math>x = (x_1, x_2)</math>
Here the position named x is identified by a pair of numbers <math>x_1</math> and <math>x_2</math>. The co-ordinates are numbered, 1 and 2. We do not call the co-ordinates ''x'' and ''y'', as is sometimes done, because there is going to be more co-ordinates later (eventually 4, for General Relativity). Writing the co-ordinate axis as a subscript will greatly simplify the notation later.
For two points, :<math>x = (x_1, x_2)</math> :<math>y = (y_1, y_2)</math>
then the distance measure between two points is, :<math>|x - y| = \sqrt{(x_1 - y_1)^2 + (x_1 - y_1)^2} </math>
The notation may be simplified by allowing summing over the co-ordinates. For example the the above distance measure formula may be simplified using a sum over co-ordinates as, :<math>|x - y| = \sqrt{\sum_\mu (x_\mu - y_\mu)^2} </math>
The use of Greek letters is nothing to worry about. Mathematicians use Greek letters to broaden the set of letters they can use for variables. Mathematicians don't usually declare there variables with types, as is done in computer science. But none of this anything to worry about.
Now as shapes are rotated by pushing the first button (the one that appears to rotate the objects around the center of the screens) the lengths of sides remains unchanged. In other words the length is invariant. If we measure the same sides after rotations which we will name <math>\alpha</math> and <math> eta</math> :<math>\sum_\mu (x^\alpha_\mu - y^\alpha_\mu)^2 = \sum_\mu (x^ eta_\mu - y^ eta_\mu)^2</math>
These rotations may also be considered co-ordinate transforms. Actually a co-ordinate system is defined by us in examining the world, which is somewhat hard to think about. It is easier, at least to start with, to think about the world being rotated around our fixed co-ordinate system. But later we must get used to the idea of different co-ordinate system.
Because co-ordinate systems are compared so often in relativity, instead of using alpha and beta we will often refer to the primed and un-primed co-ordinate system. :<math>\sum_\mu (x_\mu - y_\mu)^2 = \sum_\mu (x'_\mu - y'_\mu)^2</math>
In understanding mathematical notation, we will often see that the goal of the mathematician is the simplest most concise notation possible (even if it is somewhat un-intuitive). Mathematics arose long before computers, and everything had to be written by hand. We will need to get use to this mathematical notation. But however it is dressed up mathematical notation usually means something that is essentially simple.
===The dot product===
The dot product is needed. :<math>x \cdot y = x_1 y_1 + x_2 y_2</math>
Or more generally, :<math>x \cdot y = \sum x_\mu y_\mu</math>
The dot product may be used to express the measure of distance, :<math>(x-y) \cdot (x-y) = |x-y|^2</math>
The distance from the will be written, :<math>x \cdot x = |x|^2</math>
===The Euclidian metric===
A metric is a matrix of data required to measure distance. It is represented as ''g'' in, :<math>|x|^2 = \sum_{\mu, 
u} g_{\mu 
u} x_\mu x_
u</math>
Comparing this with, :<math>|x|^2 = \sum_\mu x_\mu^2 </math>
Then <math>g = \delta</math> where <math>\delta</math> is called the Kronecker delta, defined as, :<math> \mu 
e 
u \implies \delta_{\mu 
u} = 0 </math> :<math> \delta_{\mu 
u} = 1 </math>
Then <math>\delta = g</math> gives, :<math>\sum_{\mu, 
u} \delta_{\mu 
u} x_\mu x_
u = \sum_\mu x_\mu x_\mu = \sum_\mu x_\mu^2 = |x|^2</math>
The metric will be important later when we consider curved space. Then <math>g 
e \delta</math> and may vary with position.
===Rotation in the third dimension (the second button)===
When the second button is pushed the shapes change, and appear to tumble over each other. Small rotations allow us to track objects as they change shape, but distances change.
Everything we had when pushing the first button disappears. Distances are no longer invariant. This would be quite a shock if previously we had only known about 2 dimensions.
A simple generalization of the distance measure resolves the problem, :<math>|x-y|^2 = (x_1 - y_1)^2 + (x_2 - y_2)^2 + (x_3 - y_3)^2 = \sum_\mu (x_\mu - y_\mu)^2</math>
Then by assuming this distance is invariant it is possible to assign distances to objects that are consistent with the apparent changing of shape of the objects. What this shows is that the shadows we see are not the reality. The reality is that the shadows are images of an object in 3 dimensions displayed in 2 dimensions.
==The special relativity shadow box==
Around the 1900s physics, which had been doing very well in explaining the world, started to have a few problems. The behavior of fast moving electrons did not seemed to make sense. They behaved as if there length had been contracted in the direction of movement.
Physics had also met problems in another area. Maxwell's equations of electo-magnetism had unified the electric and the magnetic fields and even explained light. But they also describe a wave, and as we all know, waves need a medium to travel through. The physicists named this medium was named the ether.
The earth is travelling fairly fast through the universe, so if the ether was stationary, it should be possible to detect the motion of the earth through the universe. What you would expect is that the speed of light would be different if measured in different directions. Michelson and Morley set up an experiment to test this result using an incredibly accurate device called an interferometer.
But, to there surprise, there results were negative. Whichever way they looked the speed of light was stubbornly the same. This seemed to defy the laws of logic because how can the speed of something be the same, no matter how fast you are going relative to it.
===Minkowski metric===
What if the 3 dimensional space we see is a shadow box, of a 4 dimensional structure? The Michelson, Morley experiment takes us straight to the fundamental result. It says that the speed of light is invariant, no matter how you measure it.
Then in a 3 dimensional co-ordinate system, with time, if a beam of light is omitted from the origin and received at a point ''x'' some time ''t'' later, then. :<math>\sum_\mu x_\mu^2 = c^2 t^2</math>
Or, :<math>\sum_\mu x_\mu^2 - c^2 t^2 = 0</math>
and this will be true even in any co-ordinate system no matter co-ordinate system moving at uniform speed relative to each other. Then, :<math>\sum_\mu x_\mu^2 - c^2 t^2</math>
may be thought of as a generalized distance in space time. The time ''t'' is then identified as a dimension in ''x'' and is called <math>x_0</math>. The metric is then given by,
:<math>g_{0, 0} = -c^2</math> :<math>\mu 
e 0 \implies g_{\mu, \mu} = 1</math> :<math>\mu 
e 
u \implies g_{\mu, 
u} = 0</math>
Hopefully the Michelson Morley result is not so shocking in light of the shadow box experiment. The invariance it represents is a deeper order in the universe, showing the interrelation of space-time as a single four dimensional co-ordinate system, with its own metric.
===Lorentz transformation===
???? work in progress - lot of tidying up to do - not going very smoothly ????
We say a frame of reference is inertial if it is moving with a constant velocity to another. How do positions in one frame of reference transform into another frame of reference?
The assumptions are, * The two axis of the reference frames are parallel. * The transformation between frames depends only the velocity. ** The transformation from frame to the primed frame uses a velcoity ''v''. ** The transformation from primed frame to the frame uses a velcoity ''-v''. * The speed of light as measured in the two frames is constant. ** The difference in position divided by the difference in time of a light particle recorded at two positions is always the constant ''c''. * In the transformation, each component in the reference frame is a linear combination of the components in the primed frame.
The last condition is expressed as, :<math>x_\mu = \sum_
u m_{\mu,
u} x'_
u</math>
where <math>m_{\mu,
u}</math> are the components of the transformation matrix.
One approach would be two put this transformation into the Minkowski metric, :<math>(\sum_\mu x_\mu^2) - c^2 t^2 = (\sum_\mu (x'_\mu - v_\mu t')^2) - c^2 t'^2 </math> :<math>(\sum_\mu (x_\mu + v_\mu t)^2) - c^2 t^2 = (\sum_\mu x'^2) - c^2 t'^2 </math>
This is mathematically difficult. See [[w:Derivations of the Lorentz transformations#Hyperbolic geometry|Hyperbolic geometry]].
====Derivation====
The usual approach is to assume that the frames move relative to each other along one co-ordinate axis. This approach is described at [[w:Derivations of the Lorentz transformations|Derivations of the Lorentz transformations]]. These derivations are simpler in some ways, but also more confusing in other ways. They rely on understanding the physical situation, where as I want a derivation that puts all the facts in to the formula, and arrives at the result. Each step should be a simple no-brainer, even the derivation is a bit longer.
To make the derivation more understandable take <math>t = x_0</math> and let the indexes go from 1 to 3 (missing out 0). Then,
:<math>x_\mu = m_{\mu,0} t' + \sum_
u m_{\mu,
u} x'_
u</math> (Equation 1) :<math>t = m_{0, 0} t' + \sum_
u m_{0,
u} x'_
u</math> (Equation 2)
====Distance and the moving frames====
The two reference systems are moving with a relative constant velocity ''v'' in a direction '''e''' (given by a unit vector). So at, <math>\mathbf{x} = (0, 0, 0)</math>, <math>\mathbf{x}' = v t' \mathbf{e}</math>. This equation may be written, :<math>x'_
u = v t' e_
u</math>
Note: There is an assumption here that <math>\mathbf{e}</math> and <math>\mathbf{e}'</math> are the same. This assumes that the co-ordinate axis are parallel.
(Equation 1) which applies for any <math>x'_\mu</math>. The general formula may be applied to describe the origin of the co-ordinate systems. Substituting, :<math>x_
u</math> for <math>0</math> :<math>x'_
u</math> for <math>v t' e_
u</math> in (equation 1) gives, :<math>0 = m_{\mu,0} t' + \sum_
u m_{\mu,
u} v t' e_
u</math>
which simplifies to, :<math>0 = m_{\mu,0} + v \sum_
u m_{\mu,
u} e_
u</math>
and then, :<math>- rac{m_{\mu,0}}{v} = \sum_
u m_{\mu,
u} e_
u</math>
This suggests a more natural constant for <math>(\mu,0)</math>. Define, <math>n_{\mu,0}</math> as, :<math> n_{\mu,0} = - rac{m_{\mu,0}}{v}</math> (definition 1)
then, :<math> n_{\mu,0} = \sum_
u m_{\mu,
u} e_
u</math>
Then define <math>n_{\mu,
u}</math> as, :<math>m_{\mu,
u} = n_{\mu,0} n_{\mu,
u} </math> (definition 2)
then, :<math>n_{\mu,0} = \sum_
u n_{\mu,0} n_{\mu,
u} e_
u = n_{\mu,0} \sum_
u n_{\mu,
u} e_
u</math> gives, :<math>1 = \sum_
u n_{\mu,
u} e_
u</math> (equation 3)
Substituting the (definition 1) and (definition2) into (equation 1) gives, :<math>x_\mu = n_{\mu,0} (-v t' + \sum_
u n_{\mu,
u} x'_
u)</math> (equation 4a) :<math>x'_\mu = n_{\mu,0} (v t + \sum_
u n_{\mu,
u} x_
u)</math> (equation 4a)
====Distance and the constant speed of light====
Two reference frames are moving relative to each other in a direction '''e''' with a velocity ''v''.
A light particle moving from the origin to a point '''x''' in the direction of '''e''' will always be measured to have a velocity c, :<math>\mathbf{x} = c t \mathbf{e}</math>
The same light particle will appear to travel from the origin to ''x''', :<math>\mathbf{x}' = c t' \mathbf{e}</math>
These equations may be written as, :<math>x_\mu = c t e\mu</math> :<math>x'_\mu = c t' e\mu</math>
These equations represent another specific situation which the general equations must satisfy. Substituting, :<math>x_\mu</math> by <math>c t e\mu</math> :<math>x'_\mu</math> by <math>c t' e\mu</math> in (equation 4a) and (equation 4b) gives, :<math>c t e_\mu = n_{\mu,0} (-v t' + \sum_
u n_{\mu,
u} c t' e_
u)</math> :<math>c t' e_\mu = n_{\mu,0} (+v t + \sum_
u n_{\mu,
u} c t e_
u)</math>
which may be simplified as, :<math>c t e_\mu = t' n_{\mu,0} (-v + c \sum_
u n_{\mu,
u} e_
u)</math> :<math>c t' e_\mu = t n_{\mu,0} (+v + c \sum_
u n_{\mu,
u} e_
u)</math>
But (equation 3) is, :<math>\sum_
u n_{\mu,
u} e_
u = 1</math>
so, :<math>c t e_\mu = t' n_{\mu,0} (c + v)</math> :<math>c t' e_\mu = t n_{\mu,0} (c - v)</math>
multiplying each side of each equation gives, :<math>c^2 e_\mu^2 = n_{\mu,0}^2 (c + v)(c - v)</math> :<math>n_{\mu,0}^2 =  rac{e_\mu^2}{1 -  rac{v^2}{c^2}}</math>
Define <math>\alpha</math> as, :<math>\alpha = \sqrt{ rac{1}{1 -  rac{v^2}{c^2}}}</math>
then, :<math>n_{\mu,0} = e_\mu \alpha</math>
and, :<math>x_\mu = e_\mu \alpha (-v t' + \sum_
u n_{\mu,
u} x'_
u)</math> (equation 5a) :<math>x'_\mu = e_\mu \alpha (v t + \sum_
u n_{\mu,
u} x_
u)</math> (equation 5a)
====Time and moving reference frames====
As before the two reference systems are moving with a constant velocity ''v'' in a direction '''e''' (given by a unit vector). So at, <math>x = 0</math>, <math>\mathbf{x}' = v t' \mathbf{e}</math>.
From (equation 2) setting <math>x'_
u = v e_
u t'</math> gives, :<math>t = m_{0, 0} t' + \sum_
u m_{0,
u} v e_
u t'</math>
which simplifies to, :<math>t = t'(m_{0, 0} + v \sum_
u m_{0,
u} e_
u)</math>
From (equation 2) by the principle of relaticity :<math>t' = m_{0, 0} t - \sum_
u m_{0,
u} x_
u</math>
Setting <math>\mathbf{x} = (0, 0, 0)</math> gives, :<math>t' = t m_{0, 0}</math>
Solving both equations for <math>t/t'</math> gives, :<math> rac{1}{m_{0, 0}} = t/t' = m_{0, 0} + v \sum_
u m_{0,
u} e_
u </math>
which simplifies to, :<math> rac{1}{m_{0, 0}} - m_{0, 0} = v \sum_
u m_{0,
u} e_
u </math>
and then, :<math>m_{0, 0}( rac{1}{m_{0, 0}}^2 - 1) = v \sum_
u m_{0,
u} e_
u </math>
Let, :<math>m_{0,
u} = m_{0, 0} n_{0,
u} </math>
then, :<math>( rac{1}{m_{0, 0}}^2 - 1) = v \sum_
u n_{0,
u} e_
u </math> (equation 7)
and, :<math>t = m_{0, 0} (t' + \sum_
u n_{0,
u} x'_
u)</math> (equation 8)
====Time and the constant speed of light====
The constancy of the speed of light allows us to instantiate, :<math>x = c t \mathbf{e}</math> :<math>x' = c t' \mathbf{e}</math>
In (equation 2) giveing, :<math>t = m_{0, 0} (t' + \sum_
u n_{0,
u} c t' e_
u)</math>
which simplifies to, :<math>t = t' m_{0, 0} (1 + c \sum_
u m_{0,
u} e_
u)</math>
and from the principle of relativity, :<math>t' = t m_{0, 0}(1 - c \sum_
u m_{0,
u} e_
u)</math>
Multiplying both sides of the two equations gives, :<math>1 = m_{0, 0}^2(1 - c^2 (\sum_
u n_{0,
u} e_
u))^2</math>
and by dividing both sides by <math>m_{0, 0}^2</math>, and subtracting 1, :<math> rac{1}{m_{0, 0}}^2 - 1 = -c^2 (\sum_
u n_{0,
u} e_
u))^2</math>
(Equation 7) gives another expression for <math> rac{1}{m_{0, 0}}^2 - 1</math>, :<math> rac{1}{m_{0, 0}}^2 - 1 = v \sum_
u n_{0,
u} e_
u </math>
So, :<math>-c^2 (\sum_
u n_{0,
u} e_
u))^2 =  rac{1}{m_{0, 0}}^2 - 1 = v \sum_
u n_{0,
u} e_
u </math>
Which simplifies to, :<math> \sum_
u n_{0,
u} e_
u = - rac{v}{c^2} </math> (equation 9)
This expression may be substituted in (equation 5) giving, :<math> rac{1}{m_{0, 0}}^2 - 1 = -v  rac{v}{c^2} = - rac{v^2}{c^2} </math>
This equation may be re-arranged as, :<math>m_{0, 0}^2 =  rac{1}{1 -  rac{v^2}{c^2}} = \alpha^2 </math>
so :<math>t = \alpha (t' - \sum_
u n_{0,
u} x'_
u)</math> (equation 10)
A simple expression that satisfies (equation 9) is, :<math>n_{0,
u} =  rac{v}{c^2} e_
u </math> (equation 11)

u} e_
